Emperor Guangwu, posthumously known as Shizu, had the personal name Xiu and the courtesy name Wenshu. (The Classic of Ritual states: "The founder has merit and the successors have virtue." Since Emperor Guangwu achieved the restoration of the Han, his temple name was Shizu.) (According to the rules of posthumous naming: "One who continues the legacy of predecessors is called 'Guang' (Bright), and one who successfully suppresses disaster and chaos is called 'Wu' (Martial).") Marquis Fu's Notes on Past and Present states: "The courtesy name of Xiu was Mao.") (Bo, Zhong, Shu, and Ji indicate the birth order of brothers.) (His eldest brother was Bosheng, and the second was Zhong; therefore, his own courtesy name was Wenshu.) ) He was a native of Caiyang in Nanyang. (Nanyang was a commandery; it is now the area around Dengzhou.) (Caiyang was a county; its former city was located southwest of present-day Zaoyang County in Suizhou.) ) He was a ninth-generation descendant of Emperor Gaozu, descending from King Ding of Changsha, named Fa, who was a son of Emperor Jing. (Changsha was a commandery; it is now the area around Tanzhou.) ) Fa was the father of Mai, the Marquis Jie of Chunling. (Chunling was the name of a township; it originally belonged to Lingdao County in Lingling, located north of present-day Tangxing County in Yongzhou. During the reign of Emperor Yuan, the people were moved to Nanyang, but the area retained the name Chunling; its former city is now east of Zaoyang County in Suizhou.) (The details are provided in the Biographies of the Four Kings of the Imperial Clan.) ) Mai was the father of Wai, who served as the Grand Administrator of Yulin. (Yulin was a commandery; it is now the area around Chenzhou.) (The Book of Han states: "The Grand Administrator of a commandery was an office established during the Qin.") (The salary rank was two thousand piculs of grain.) (Emperor Jing changed the title to 'Grand Administrator'.) ) Wai was the father of Hui, who served as the Chief Commandant of Julu. (Julu was a commandery; it is now the area around Xingzhou.) (The Book of Han states: "The Chief Commandant was originally the Commandery Commandant, a position created by the Qin.") (The duty was to assist the Grand Administrator and oversee military affairs; the salary rank was equivalent to two thousand piculs.) (Emperor Jing changed the title to 'Chief Commandant'.) ) Hui was the father of Qin, who served as the Prefect of Nandun. (Nandun was a county belonging to the Runan Commandery; its former city was located west of present-day Xiangcheng County in Chenzhou.) (The Book of Han states: "The offices of Prefect (Ling) and Chief (Zhang) were both established by the Qin.") (A county with ten thousand or more households had a Prefect, with a salary rank between one thousand and six hundred piculs.) (A county with fewer than ten thousand households had a Chief, with a salary rank between five hundred and three hundred piculs.) ) Qin was the father of Emperor Guangwu. Emperor Guangwu was orphaned at the age of nine and was raised by his paternal uncle, Liang. He stood seven chi and three cun tall, with a fine beard and eyebrows, a wide mouth, a high-bridged nose, and a forehead that displayed the 'sun-horn' protuberance. (The term long means high or prominent.) (Xu Fu states: "The tip of the nose is called the zhun.") (Zheng Xuan, in his commentary on the Zhonghou chapter of the Book of Documents, states: "The 'sun-horn' refers to a bone rising in the middle of the forehead, shaped like the sun.") ) By nature, he was diligent in farming. (Sowing is called jia, and harvesting is called se.) ) His elder brother, Bosheng, was fond of chivalrous deeds and maintained a following of retainers; he often mocked Emperor Guangwu for being preoccupied with farming, comparing him to Emperor Gaozu's brother, Zhong. (Zhong refers to Liu Xi, the Marquis of Heyang, who was skilled at managing property and assets.) (See the Book of Han.) ) During the Tianfeng era of Wang Mang's reign, (In the sixth year of the Jianguo era, Wang Mang changed the era name to Tianfeng.) ) Emperor Guangwu traveled to Chang'an to study the Classic of History, where he gained a broad understanding of its essential principles. (The Records of the Eastern Tower states: "He studied the Classic of History under Xu Ziwei of Lujiang, who was a Palace Attendant.") ("Short on funds, he and his roommate, a student named Han, pooled their money to buy a donkey. They had their attendants hire it out to others to cover their collective expenses.") )

è½æœ«ï¼Œå¤©ä¸‹é€£æ­²ç½è—ï¼Œå¯‡ç›œé‹’èµ·ã€‚ ã€ˆè¨€è³Šé‹’éŠ³ç«¶èµ·ã€‚ å­—æˆ–ä½œã€Œèœ‚ã€ï¼Œè«­å¤šä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ åœ°çš‡ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œ ã€ˆå¤©é³³å…­å¹´æ”¹ç‚ºåœ°çš‡ã€‚ ã€‰ å—é™½è’é¥‘ï¼Œ ã€ˆã€ŠéŸ“è©©å¤–å‚³ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸€ç©€ä¸å‡æ›°æ­‰ï¼ŒäºŒç©€ä¸å‡æ›°é¥‘ï¼Œä¸‰ç©€ä¸å‡æ›°é¥‰ï¼Œå››ç©€ä¸å‡æ›°è’ï¼Œäº”ç©€ä¸å‡æ›°å¤§ä¾µã€‚ ã€ã€‰ è«¸å®¶è³”å®¢å¤šç‚ºå°ç›œã€‚ å…‰æ­¦é¿åæ–°é‡ï¼Œ ã€ˆæ–°é‡å±¬å—é™½éƒ¡ï¼Œä»Šé„§å·ç¸£ã€‚ ã€ŠçºŒæ¼¢æ›¸ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¼¯å‡è³”å®¢åŠ«äººï¼Œä¸Šé¿åæ–¼æ–°é‡é„§æ™¨å®¶ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ å› è³£æ¦–æ–¼å®›ã€‚ ã€ˆã€Šæ±è§€è¨˜ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ™‚å—é™½æ—±é¥‘ï¼Œè€Œä¸Šç”°ç¨æ”¶ã€‚ ã€å®›ï¼Œç¸£ï¼Œå±¬å—é™½éƒ¡ï¼Œæ•…åŸä»Šé„§å·å—é™½ç¸£ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ å®›äººæé€šç­‰ä»¥åœ–è®–èªªå…‰æ­¦äº‘ï¼šã€ŒåŠ‰æ°å¾©èµ·ï¼Œææ°ç‚ºè¼”ã€‚ã€ ã€ˆåœ–ï¼Œæ²³åœ–ä¹Ÿã€‚ è®–ï¼Œç¬¦å‘½ä¹‹æ›¸ã€‚ è®–ï¼Œé©—ä¹Ÿã€‚ è¨€ç‚ºç‹è€…å—å‘½ä¹‹å¾µé©—ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€Šæ˜“å¤éˆåœ–ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ¼¢ä¹‹è‡£æé™½ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€ã€‰ å…‰æ­¦åˆä¸æ•¢ç•¶ï¼Œç„¶ç¨å¿µå…„ä¼¯å‡ç´ çµè¼•å®¢ï¼Œå¿…èˆ‰å¤§äº‹ï¼Œä¸”ç‹è½æ•—äº¡å·²å…†ï¼Œå¤©ä¸‹æ–¹äº‚ï¼Œé‚èˆ‡å®šè¬€ï¼Œæ–¼æ˜¯ä¹ƒå¸‚å…µå¼©ã€‚ åæœˆï¼Œèˆ‡æé€šå¾å¼Ÿè»¼ç­‰èµ·æ–¼å®›ï¼Œæ™‚å¹´äºŒåå…«ã€‚
Toward the end of Wang Mang's reign, the empire suffered consecutive years of natural disasters and locust plagues, and banditry erupted everywhere with sharp intensity. (This means the bandits rose up in competition with sharp vigor.) (The character is sometimes written as 'bee,' serving as a metaphor for their great numbers.) ) In the third year of the Dihuang era, (In the sixth year of the Tianfeng era, the era name was changed to Dihuang.) ) A severe famine struck Nanyang. (The Illustrations of Han's Odes states: "When one type of grain does not grow, it is called qian; when two types do not grow, it is ji; when three types do not grow, it is jin; when four types do not grow, it is huang; and when five types do not grow, it is daqin (great famine).") ) Many of the retainers from various prominent families turned to petty theft. To avoid trouble with the local officials, Emperor Guangwu went into hiding in Xinye. (Xinye belonged to the Nanyang Commandery; it is now part of Dengzhou.) (The Continued Book of Han states: "Because Bosheng's retainers had robbed people, the Emperor sought refuge from the officials at the home of Deng Chen in Xinye.") ) Consequently, he went to Wan to sell grain. (The Records of the Eastern Tower states: "At that time, Nanyang suffered from drought and famine, yet the Emperor's fields alone yielded a harvest.") (Wan was a county belonging to the Nanyang Commandery; its former city is the present-day Nanyang in Dengzhou.) ) Li Tong and others from Wan used prophetic charts to persuade Emperor Guangwu, saying: "The Liu clan shall rise again, and the Li clan shall serve as their supporters." (The 'charts' refer to the Yellow River Chart.) (The 'prophecies' refer to books regarding the mandates and omens.) (The term chen also implies verification.) (This means they serve as signs and verifications for a king receiving the Mandate of Heaven.) (The Kunling Chart of the Classic of Changes states: "The minister of Han shall be Li Yang.") ) At first, Emperor Guangwu did not dare to accept such talk. However, he reflected that his brother Bosheng had long been associating with adventurous retainers and would certainly attempt a great undertaking. Furthermore, as the omens of Wang Mang's downfall were already appearing and the empire was in turmoil, he eventually joined in the planning and began to purchase weapons and crossbows. In the tenth month, he rose in rebellion at Wan alongside Li Tong's cousin Li Yi and others; he was twenty-eight years old at the time.

In the eleventh month, a comet appeared in the constellation Zhang. (The Book of Han: Phonetics and Meanings states: "A comet (beixing) has short light rays and appears fluffy.") (Zhang is a southern constellation.) (The Continued Han Treatises state: "Zhang corresponds to the region of Zhou.") ("When a comet appears in Zhang and travels southeast, it enters the divisions of the constellations Yi and Zhen.") ("The constellations Yi and Zhen correspond to the land of Chu; this indicated that military unrest would soon occur in that region.") ("In the first month of the following year, Emperor Guangwu raised troops at Chunling and attacked Nanyang, beheading Zhen Fu, Liang Qiuci, and others, and killing tens of thousands of their soldiers.") ("When Emperor Guangwu established his capital at Luoyang, he resided in the land of Zhou; this was an omen of clearing away the old and spreading the new.") ) Emperor Guangwu then led his retainers back to Chunling. At that time, Bosheng had already gathered a following and raised troops. Initially, the young men of various local families were terrified; they all fled into hiding, exclaiming, "Bosheng is going to get us killed!" But when they saw Emperor Guangwu in his crimson robe and large ceremonial crown, (Dong Ba's Treatise on Chariots and Costumes states: "The 'large crown' refers to the military crown, worn by military officials.") (The Records of the Eastern Tower states: "At that time, the Emperor wore a crimson robe and a large crown, which was the uniform of a general.") ) they were all amazed and said, "If even someone as prudent and steady as he is doing this, then we have nothing to fear," and they began to feel more at ease. Bosheng then recruited troops from Xinshi and Pinglin. (Xinshi was a county belonging to the Jiangxia Commandery; its former city is located northeast of present-day Fushui County in Yingzhou.) (Pinglin is the name of a place located northeast of present-day Sui County in Suizhou.) ) Together with their leaders Wang Feng and Chen Mu, they struck westward at the Chang settlement. (The Guangya states: "Ju means a place of residence; its pronunciation is ci-yu.") (The Book of Han: Phonetics and Meanings states: "An area smaller than a township is called a ju.") ) Initially, Emperor Guangwu rode an ox into battle; it was only after killing the Commandant of Xinye that he obtained a horse. (The Book of Han states that the Commandant was an office established by the Qin, with a salary rank between four hundred and two hundred piculs.) ) They advanced and slaughtered the inhabitants of Tangzi Township. (The rules state: "When many are executed or killed, it is called tu (slaughter).") (Tangzi Township is the site of Mount Tangzi, located southwest of present-day Huyang County in Tangzhou.) ) They also killed the Commandant of Huyang. (Huyang belonged to the Nanyang Commandery; it is now part of Tangzhou.) (The Records of the Eastern Tower states: "Liu Zhong falsely identified himself as an official from Jiangxia to lure and kill him.") ) Within the army, the distribution of spoils was unequal, causing resentment among the troops, who then considered turning against the members of the Liu clan. Emperor Guangwu collected the goods that his own kinsmen had received and gave them all to the disgruntled soldiers, at which point the troops were satisfied. They advanced and captured Jiyang. (Jiyang was the name of a county belonging to the Nanyang Commandery, located on the north bank of the Ji River; it was the site of the ancient state of Xie, and its former city is northwest of present-day Huyang County in Tangzhou.) (The character ji is pronounced ji-li.) ) They engaged with Wang Mang's Grand Administrator of the Front Division, Zhen Fu, (Wang Mang established six divisions (dui), with each commandery having one Grand Administrator (dafu), whose duties were similar to those of a Grand Administrator (taishou).) (Nanyang was the Front Division, Henei the Rear, Yingchuan the Left, Hongnong the Right, Hedong the Zhao, and Xingyang the Qi.) (The character dui is pronounced like sui.) ) and the Chief of the Division, Liang Qiuci. (Wang Mang established one Chief of the Division (shuzheng) for each division, whose duties were similar to those of a Chief Commandant (duwei).) ) They fought at Little Chang'an. (The Continued Book of Han states that Yuyang County contained the Little Chang'an settlement; its former city is located south of present-day Nanyang in Dengzhou.) ) The Han army suffered a major defeat and retreated to defend Jiyang.
4

On the xinsi day of the second month, Liu Shenggong was established as the Emperor. Bosheng was appointed Grand Minister over the Masses, and Emperor Guangwu was appointed Grand Master of Ceremonies and Lieutenant General. (The Book of Han states: "The Minister of Ceremonies (fengchang) was an office established by the Qin.") (Emperor Jing changed the title to 'Grand Master of Ceremonies' (taichang).) (Ying Shao's Ceremonial Protocols of the Han Officials states: "The title 'Grand Master of Ceremonies' was chosen with the hope that the state would be grand and prosperous and the altars of the land and grain would endure forever.") (Laozi stated: "The Lieutenant General takes the position on the left, while the Superior General takes the position on the right.") (The Records of the Eastern Tower states: "At that time, there was no official seal available, so he obtained the seal of the household assistant to the Marquis of Dingwu and wore it when he entered the court.") )

åˆé©…è«¸çŒ›ç¸ ã€ˆã€ŒçŒ›ã€æˆ–ä½œã€Œç·ã€ã€‚ ç·ï¼ŒçŒ›è²Œä¹Ÿï¼ŒéŸ³å¤çŒ›åã€‚ ã€‰ è™è±¹çŠ€è±¡ä¹‹å±¬ï¼Œä»¥åŠ©å¨æ­¦ã€‚ è‡ªç§¦ã€æ¼¢å‡ºå¸«ä¹‹ç››ï¼Œæœªç”æœ‰ä¹Ÿã€‚ å…‰æ­¦å°‡æ•¸åƒå…µï¼Œå¾¼ä¹‹æ–¼é™½é—œã€‚ ã€ˆå­¥ï¼Œå­ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ æ¬²æ•£æ­¸è«¸åŸã€‚ å…‰æ­¦è­°æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šå…µç³“æ—£å°‘ï¼Œè€Œå¤–å¯‡å½Šå¤§ï¼Œå¹¶åŠ›ç¦¦ä¹‹ï¼ŒåŠŸåº¶å¯ç«‹ï¼› å¦‚æ¬²åˆ†æ•£ï¼Œå‹¢ç„¡ä¿±å…¨ã€‚ ä¸”å®›åŸæœªæ‹”ï¼Œ ã€ˆè¬‚ä¼¯å‡åœä¹‹æœªæ‹”ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ ä¸èƒ½ç›¸æ•‘ï¼Œæ˜†é™½å³ç ´ï¼Œä¸€æ—¥ä¹‹é–’ï¼Œè«¸éƒ¨äº¦æ»…çŸ£ã€‚ ä»Šä¸åŒå¿ƒè†½å…±èˆ‰åŠŸåï¼Œåæ¬²å®ˆå¦»å­è²¡ç‰©é‚ªï¼Ÿ ã€è«¸å°‡æ€’æ›°ï¼šã€ŒåŠ‰å°‡è»ä½•æ•¢å¦‚æ˜¯ï¼ ã€å…‰æ­¦ç¬‘è€Œèµ·ã€‚ æœƒå€™é¨é‚„ï¼Œè¨€å¤§å…µä¸”è‡³åŸåŒ—ï¼Œè»é™³æ•¸ç™¾é‡Œï¼Œä¸è¦‹å…¶å¾Œã€‚ è«¸å°‡é½ç›¸è¬‚æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ›´è«‹åŠ‰å°‡è»è¨ˆä¹‹ã€‚ ã€å…‰æ­¦å¾©ç‚ºåœ–ç•«æˆæ•—ã€‚ è«¸å°‡æ†‚è¿«ï¼Œçš†æ›°ã€Œè«¾ã€ã€‚ æ™‚åŸä¸­å”¯æœ‰å…«ä¹åƒäººï¼Œå…‰æ­¦ä¹ƒä½¿æˆåœ‹ä¸Šå…¬ç‹é³³ã€å»·å°‰å¤§å°‡è»ç‹å¸¸ç•™å®ˆï¼Œå¤œè‡ªèˆ‡é©ƒé¨å¤§å°‡è»å®—ä½»ã€ ã€ˆé©ƒé¨å¤§å°‡è»ï¼Œæ­¦å¸ç½®ï¼Œè‡ªéœå»ç—…å§‹ã€‚ ä½»éŸ³å¤ªå ¯åã€‚ ã€‰ äº”å¨å°‡è»æè»¼ç­‰åä¸‰é¨ï¼Œ ã€ˆç‹è½ç½®äº”å¨å°‡è»ï¼Œå…¶è¡£æœä¾äº”æ–¹ä¹‹è‰²ï¼Œä»¥å¨å¤©ä¸‹ã€‚ æè»¼åˆèµ·ï¼ŒçŒ¶å‡ä»¥ç‚ºè™Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ å‡ºåŸå—é–€ï¼Œæ–¼å¤–æ”¶å…µã€‚ æ™‚è½è»åˆ°åŸä¸‹è€…ä¸”åè¬ï¼Œå…‰æ­¦å¹¾ä¸å¾—å‡ºã€‚ ã€ˆå¹¾éŸ³ç¥ˆã€‚ ã€‰ æ—£è‡³éƒ¾ã€å®šé™µï¼Œæ‚‰ç™¼è«¸ç‡Ÿå…µï¼Œè€Œè«¸å°‡è²ªæƒœè²¡è²¨ï¼Œæ¬²åˆ†ç•™å®ˆä¹‹ã€‚ å…‰æ­¦æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šè‹¥ç ´æ•µï¼Œçç¤è¬å€ï¼Œ ã€ˆç¤ï¼Œå¤ã€Œå¯¶ã€å­—ã€‚ ã€‰ å¤§åŠŸå¯æˆï¼› å¦‚ç‚ºæ‰€æ•—ï¼Œé¦–é ˜ç„¡é¤˜ï¼Œä½•è²¡ç‰©ä¹‹æœ‰ï¼ ã€è¡†ä¹ƒå¾ã€‚
Earlier, Wang Mang had summoned hundreds of individuals from sixty-three schools of military strategy across the empire, appointing them all as military officers. He selected and trained his personal guards and recruited fierce warriors. (The Shuowen Jiezi states: "Mu means to seek widely.") ) Banners, flags, and supply wagons stretched for a thousand li without interruption. (The Rites of Zhou states: "Banners made of split feathers are called jing, and those depicting bears and tigers are called qi.") ("Zi is the name of a type of carriage.") (The Shiming states: "Zi implies 'mixed' (ce).") ("It refers to the practice of loading military provisions and various items together in a mixed fashion.") ("Because the load is heavy and accumulated, they are called zizhong (supply trains).") (The character zhong in this context is pronounced zhi-yong.) ) At that time, there was a giant named Ju Wuba. (Han Bo, a governor under Wang Mang, reported: "There is a remarkable man, one zhang tall and ten girths in circumference, who calls himself Ju Wuba. He comes from the area northwest of the Five Cities and southeast of Penglai. He was summoned to the seacoast, but no light carriage could carry him, and even three horses could not pull him. When he sleeps, he uses a drum as a pillow, and he eats with iron chopsticks.") (See the Book of Han.) ) He stood one zhang tall and measured ten girths in circumference, and was appointed as the Rampart Commandant. (Zheng Xuan's commentary on the Rites of Zhou states: "An army's defensive wall is called a lei.") (Cui Yuan's Admonition to the Colonel of the Central Ramparts states: "The majestic Yellow Emperor established ramparts and walls.") ("The 'Commandant' was the officer in charge of the affairs of the ramparts and walls.") ) They also drove a variety of fierce beasts, (The character meng (fierce) is sometimes written as guang.) (The character guang means a fierce appearance; it is pronounced gu-meng.) ) including tigers, leopards, rhinoceroses, and elephants, to bolster their military might. Not since the heights of the Qin and Han dynasties had such a magnificent army been sent forth. Emperor Guangwu led several thousand troops to intercept them at Yangguan. (This is the name of a settlement.) (Li Daoyuan's Commentary on the Water Classic states: "The Ying River flows southeast through the Yangguan settlement; the settlement flanks the river on both sides.") (It is located northwest of present-day Yangzhai County in Luozhou.) ) When the various generals saw the overwhelming strength of the armies under Wang Xun and Wang Yi, they retreated and galloped back into Kunyang, all of them terrified and anxious for the safety of their wives and children. (The term nu refers to children.) ) They wanted to disperse and return to their respective cities. Emperor Guangwu advised them, saying: "Currently, our troops and provisions are scarce, while the enemy outside is powerful. If we combine our forces to resist them, we may yet achieve success." "If we choose to disperse, neither group will survive the situation." "Furthermore, the city of Wan has not yet been captured," (This refers to the fact that Bosheng's siege of the city had not yet succeeded.) ) "and we cannot reinforce each other. If Kunyang falls, all our various divisions will be wiped out within a single day." "Now, instead of uniting our hearts and courage to achieve glory together, do you really wish to stay and guard only your wives, children, and property?" The various generals reacted angrily, saying, "How dare General Liu speak to us like this!" Emperor Guangwu simply laughed and stood up. Just then, the scouts returned and reported that the main enemy force was approaching the north of the city. Their battle formation stretched for hundreds of li, and the rear of the column was nowhere in sight. The generals suddenly turned to one another and said, "We must ask General Liu to devise a plan for us after all." Emperor Guangwu once again mapped out the possibilities of success and failure for them. Pressed by their anxiety, the generals all agreed to his plan. At that time, there were only eight or nine thousand men in the city. Emperor Guangwu ordered Wang Feng, the Superior Duke of Chenguo, and Wang Chang, the Grand General of the Court Architect, to remain and defend the city. At night, he personally led the Grand General of the Flying Cavalry, Zong Tiao, (The rank of Grand General of the Flying Cavalry was established by Emperor Wu, beginning with Huo Qubing.) (The character tiao is pronounced tai-yao.) ) and thirteen horsemen, including the General of Five Powers Li Yi, (Wang Mang established the 'Generals of Five Powers,' whose clothing matched the colors of the five directions to overawe the empire.) (When Li Yi first rose in rebellion, he still used this title as a pretense.) ) and they exited through the south gate of the city to gather reinforcements from the outside. At that time, nearly a hundred thousand of Wang Mang's troops had already arrived at the city walls, and Emperor Guangwu narrow escaped being unable to exit. (The character ji is pronounced qi.) ) Once they reached Yan and Dingling, they mobilized all the troops from the various camps. However, many of the generals, greedy for their wealth and property, wanted to keep part of the force behind to guard their possessions. Emperor Guangwu said, "If we defeat the enemy now, we will gain ten thousand times more treasure than this." (The character bao used here is an ancient form of the word for 'treasure.') ) "A great achievement is within our grasp." "If we are defeated, our heads will not remain on our shoulders; what good will wealth and property be then?" The troops then followed his advice.

åš´å°¤èªªç‹é‚‘æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ˜†é™½åŸå°è€Œå …ï¼Œä»Šå‡è™Ÿè€…åœ¨å®›ï¼ŒäºŸé€²å¤§å…µ ã€ˆäºŸï¼Œæ€¥ä¹Ÿï¼ŒéŸ³ç´€åŠ›åã€‚ ã€‰ ï¼Œå½¼å¿…å¥”èµ°ï¼› å®›æ•—ï¼Œæ˜†é™½è‡ªæœã€‚ ã€é‚‘æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾æ˜”ä»¥è™ç‰™å°‡è»åœç¿Ÿç¾©ï¼Œåä¸ç”Ÿå¾—ï¼Œä»¥è¦‹è²¬è®“ã€‚ ã€ˆç¿Ÿç¾©å­—æ–‡ä»²ï¼Œæ–¹é€²å°‘å­ï¼Œç‚ºæ±éƒ¡å¤ªå®ˆã€‚ ç‹è½å±…æ”ï¼Œç¾©å¿ƒæƒ¡ä¹‹ï¼Œä¹ƒç«‹æ±å¹³ç‹é›²å­ä¿¡ç‚ºå¤©å­ï¼Œç¾©è‡ªè™ŸæŸ±å¤©å¤§å°‡è»ï¼Œä»¥èª…è½ã€‚ è½ä¹ƒä½¿å­«å»ºã€ç‹é‚‘ç­‰å°‡å…µæ“Šç¾©ï¼Œç ´ä¹‹ã€‚ ç¾©äº¡ï¼Œè‡ªæ®ºï¼Œæ•…åä¸ç”Ÿå¾—ã€‚ åéŸ³æ‰å§åã€‚ è¦‹ã€Šå‰æ›¸ã€‹ã€‚ ã€‰ ä»Šå°‡ç™¾è¬ä¹‹è¡†ï¼Œé‡åŸè€Œä¸èƒ½ä¸‹ï¼Œä½•è¬‚é‚ªï¼Ÿã€ ã€ˆã€Œé‡ã€æˆ–ç‚ºã€Œéã€ã€‚ ã€‰ é‚åœä¹‹æ•¸åé‡ï¼Œåˆ—ç‡Ÿç™¾æ•¸ï¼Œé›²è»Šåé¤˜ä¸ˆï¼Œ ã€ˆé›²è»Šå³æ¨“è»Šï¼Œç¨±é›²ï¼Œè¨€å…¶é«˜ä¹Ÿï¼Œå‡ä¹‹ä»¥æœ›æ•µï¼ŒçŒ¶å¢¨å­äº‘ã€Œå…¬è¼¸èˆ¬ç‚ºé›²æ¢¯ä¹‹æ¢°ã€ã€‚ ã€‰ ç°è‡¨åŸä¸­ï¼Œ ã€ˆä¿¯è¦–æ›°ç°ï¼ŒéŸ³è‹¦æš«åã€‚ ã€‰ æ——å¹Ÿè”½é‡ï¼Œ ã€ˆã€Šå»£é›…ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¹Ÿï¼Œå¹¡ä¹Ÿï¼ŒéŸ³ç†¾ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ åŸƒå¡µé€£å¤©ï¼Œé‰¦é¼“ä¹‹è²èæ•¸ç™¾é‡Œã€‚ ã€ˆã€Šèªªæ–‡ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œé‰¦ï¼Œéƒä¹Ÿï¼Œä¼¼éˆ´ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ æˆ–ç‚ºåœ°é“ï¼Œè¡è¼£æ©¦åŸã€‚ ã€ˆè¡ï¼Œæ©¦è»Šä¹Ÿã€‚ è©©æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡¨è¡é–‘é–‘ã€‚ ã€è¨±æ…æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¼£ï¼Œæ¨“è»Šä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€è¼£éŸ³æ­¥è€•åã€‚ ã€‰ ç©å¼©äº‚ç™¼ï¼ŒçŸ¢ä¸‹å¦‚é›¨ï¼ŒåŸä¸­è² æˆ¶è€Œæ±²ã€‚ ç‹é³³ç­‰ä¹é™ï¼Œä¸è¨±ã€‚ å°‹ã€é‚‘è‡ªä»¥ç‚ºåŠŸåœ¨æ¼åˆ»ï¼Œæ„æ°£ç”šé€¸ã€‚ å¤œæœ‰æµæ˜Ÿå¢œç‡Ÿä¸­ï¼Œæ™æœ‰é›²å¦‚å£å±±ï¼Œç•¶ç‡Ÿè€Œéš•ï¼Œä¸åŠåœ°å°ºè€Œæ•£ï¼Œåå£«çš†å­ä¼ã€‚ ã€ˆã€ŠçºŒæ¼¢å¿—ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œé›²å¦‚å£å±±ï¼Œè¬‚ç‡Ÿé ­ä¹‹æ˜Ÿä¹Ÿã€‚ å æ›°ï¼šã€ç‡Ÿé ­ä¹‹æ‰€å¢œï¼Œå…¶ä¸‹è¦†è»æ®ºå°‡ï¼Œè¡€æµåƒé‡Œã€‚ ã€ã€å­éŸ³ä¸€è‘‰åã€‚ ã€‰
Yan You advised Wang Yi, saying: "The city of Kunyang is small but its defenses are strong. Currently, the pretender to the throne is in Wan. We should quickly advance our main force there," (The character ji means urgent; it is pronounced ji-li.) ) "and they will surely flee." "If Wan falls, Kunyang will surrender on its own." Wang Yi replied, "In the past, when I was the Tiger Fang General and besieged Zhai Yi, I was reprimanded because I failed to capture him alive." (Zhai Yi, courtesy name Wenzhong, was the youngest son of Zhai Fangjin and served as the Grand Administrator of Dong Commandery.) (When Wang Mang was serving as regent, Zhai Yi detested him and established Liu Xin, the son of King Yun of Dongping, as the Emperor. Zhai Yi himself took the title of Grand General of the Pillar of Heaven to overthrow Wang Mang.) (Wang Mang then sent Sun Jian, Wang Yi, and others to lead an army against Zhai Yi, and they defeated him.) (Zhai Yi fled and committed suicide, which resulted in the failure to capture him alive.) (The character zuo is pronounced cai-wo.) (See the Book of Han.) ) "Now, leading a million troops, if we encounter a city and cannot capture it, what will people say?" (The character 'encounter' is sometimes written as 'pass'.) ) They then besieged the city with dozens of concentric circles of troops, establishing hundreds of camps. Their 'cloud-carriages' stood over ten zhang high, (The 'cloud-carriages' were siege towers; they were called 'cloud' because of their great height. Soldiers would ascend them to observe the enemy, much like the 'cloud-ladders' that Mozi says Gongshu Ban designed.) ) allowing them to look down into the city. (Looking down from above is called kan; it is pronounced ku-zan.) ) Their flags and banners covered the landscape, (The Guangya states: "Zhi refers to a banner; it is pronounced chi.") ) and the dust they kicked up reached the heavens. The roar of their gongs and drums could be heard for hundreds of li. (The Shuowen Jiezi states: "The zheng is a type of nao gong, shaped like a bell.") ) They also dug tunnels and used battering rams and siege towers to assault the city walls. (The term chong refers to a battering-ram carriage.) (The Classic of Poetry states: "The siege towers and battering rams move with steady purpose.") (Xu Shen states: "Peng refers to a tower carriage.") (The character peng is pronounced bu-geng.) ) A constant volley from their massed crossbows fell like rain, forcing the people inside the city to carry wooden doors over their heads when they went to draw water. Wang Feng and the others offered to surrender, but Wang Yi and Wang Xun refused to allow it. Wang Xun and Wang Yi believed that victory was only a matter of time, and their spirits were exceedingly high. One night, a meteor fell into the camp. During the day, a cloud shaped like a collapsing mountain descended directly over their camp, dispersing just a foot from the ground. The officers and soldiers were all filled with dread and cowered in fear. (The Continued Han Treatises state: "The cloud like a collapsing mountain refers to the 'star of the camp head.'") ("The divination says: 'Where the camp-head star falls, the army below shall be overturned and its generals slain, and blood shall flow for a thousand li.'") (The character yan is pronounced yi-ye.) )

å…­æœˆå·±å¯ï¼Œå…‰æ­¦é‚èˆ‡ç‡Ÿéƒ¨ä¿±é€²ï¼Œè‡ªå°‡æ­¥é¨åƒé¤˜ï¼Œå‰å»å¤§è»å››äº”é‡Œè€Œé™³ã€‚ å°‹ã€é‚‘äº¦é£å…µæ•¸åƒåˆæˆ°ã€‚ å…‰æ­¦å¥”ä¹‹ï¼Œæ–¬é¦–æ•¸åç´šã€‚ ã€ˆç§¦æ³•ï¼Œæ–¬é¦–ä¸€ï¼Œè³œçˆµä¸€ç´šï¼Œæ•…å› è¬‚æ–¬é¦–ç‚ºç´šã€‚ ã€‰ è«¸éƒ¨å–œæ›°ï¼šã€ŒåŠ‰å°‡è»å¹³ç”Ÿè¦‹å°æ•µæ€¯ï¼Œä»Šè¦‹å¤§æ•µå‹‡ï¼Œç”šå¯æ€ªä¹Ÿï¼Œä¸”å¾©å±…å‰ã€‚ è«‹åŠ©å°‡è»ï¼ ã€å…‰æ­¦å¾©é€²ï¼Œå°‹ã€é‚‘å…µå´ï¼Œè«¸éƒ¨å…±ä¹˜ä¹‹ï¼Œæ–¬é¦–æ•¸ç™¾åƒç´šã€‚ é€£å‹ï¼Œé‚å‰ã€‚ æ™‚ä¼¯å‡æ‹”å®›å·²ä¸‰æ—¥ï¼Œè€Œå…‰æ­¦å°šæœªçŸ¥ï¼Œä¹ƒå½ä½¿æŒæ›¸å ±åŸä¸­ï¼Œäº‘ã€Œå®›ä¸‹å…µåˆ°ã€ï¼Œè€Œé™½å¢¯å…¶æ›¸ã€‚ å°‹ã€é‚‘å¾—ä¹‹ï¼Œä¸æ†™ã€‚ ã€ˆæ†™éŸ³è¨±è¨˜åã€‚ ã€‰ è«¸å°‡æ—£ç¶“ç´¯æ·ï¼Œè†½æ°£ç›Šå£¯ï¼Œç„¡ä¸ä¸€ç•¶ç™¾ã€‚ å…‰æ­¦ä¹ƒèˆ‡æ•¢æ­»è€…ä¸‰åƒäººï¼Œå¾åŸè¥¿æ°´ä¸Šè¡å…¶ä¸­å …ï¼Œ ã€ˆæ•¢æ­»è¬‚æœæ•¢è€Œæ­»è€…ã€‚ å‡¡è»äº‹ï¼Œä¸­è»å°‡æœ€å°Šï¼Œå±…ä¸­ä»¥å …éŠ³è‡ªè¼”ï¼Œæ•…æ›°ä¸­å …ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ å°‹ã€é‚‘é™³äº‚ï¼Œä¹˜éŠ³å´©ä¹‹ï¼Œé‚æ®ºç‹å°‹ã€‚ åŸä¸­äº¦é¼“è­Ÿè€Œå‡ºï¼Œä¸­å¤–åˆåŸ¶ï¼Œéœ‡å‘¼å‹•å¤©åœ°ï¼Œè½å…µå¤§æ½°ï¼Œèµ°è€…ç›¸é¨°è¸ï¼Œå¥”æ®ªç™¾é¤˜é‡Œé–’ã€‚ ã€ˆæ®ªï¼Œä»†ä¹Ÿï¼ŒéŸ³æ–¼è¨ˆåã€‚ æˆ–ä½œã€Œå™ã€ã€‚ ã€‰ æœƒå¤§é›·é¢¨ï¼Œå±‹ç“¦çš†é£›ï¼Œé›¨ä¸‹å¦‚æ³¨ï¼Œæ»å·ç››æº¢ï¼Œ ã€ˆæ°´ç¶“æ›°ï¼Œæ»æ°´å‡ºå—é™½é­¯é™½ç¸£è¥¿å ¯å±±ï¼Œæ±å—ç¶“æ˜†é™½åŸåŒ—ï¼Œæ±å…¥æ±ã€‚ æ»éŸ³ç›´ç†åã€‚ ã€‰ è™è±¹çš†è‚¡æˆ°ï¼Œå£«å’çˆ­èµ´ï¼Œæººæ­»è€…ä»¥è¬æ•¸ï¼Œæ°´ç‚ºä¸æµã€‚ ã€ˆæ•¸éæ–¼è¬ï¼Œæ•…ä»¥è¬ç‚ºæ•¸ã€‚ ã€‰ ç‹é‚‘ã€åš´å°¤ã€é™³èŒ‚è¼•é¨ä¹˜æ­»äººåº¦æ°´é€ƒå»ã€‚ ç›¡ç²å…¶è»å¯¦è¼œé‡ï¼Œè»Šç”²çå¯¶ï¼Œä¸å¯å‹ç­­ï¼Œèˆ‰ä¹‹é€£æœˆä¸ç›¡ï¼Œæˆ–ç‡”ç‡’å…¶é¤˜ã€‚
On the jimao day of the sixth month, Emperor Guangwu advanced with his various camp divisions. He personally led a force of over a thousand infantry and cavalry, taking up a position four or five li ahead of the main army. Wang Xun and Wang Yi also dispatched several thousand troops to engage them. Emperor Guangwu led a charge against them, beheading several dozen of the enemy. (Under Qin law, for every head taken in battle, a soldier was granted one level of noble rank; consequently, the heads themselves came to be referred to as 'ranks' (ji).) ) The various divisions were delighted and remarked, "General Liu has always been cautious when facing small groups of enemies, yet he is extraordinarily brave when facing a great army. It is quite strange, especially since he insists on taking the lead." "Let us go and assist the General!" Emperor Guangwu advanced once more, and the troops of Wang Xun and Wang Yi began to give way. The various divisions together took advantage of the momentum, beheading hundreds or even thousands of the enemy. Following these successive victories, they continued their advance. At that time, Bosheng had already captured Wan three days prior, but Emperor Guangwu was not yet aware of it. He sent a fake messenger toward the city carrying a letter that claimed, "The army that captured Wan has arrived," and intentionally had the letter 'lost' so the enemy would find it. When Wang Xun and Wang Yi found the letter, they were greatly discouraged. (The character xi is pronounced xu-ji.) ) Having achieved a series of victories, the courage of the various generals soared, and each of them fought with the strength of a hundred men. Emperor Guangwu then led three thousand suicide-squad warriors, crossing the water from the west of the city to charge directly at the heart of the enemy's main force. (The term 'dare-to-die' refers to those who are determined and courageous enough to face death.) (In military operations, the commander of the central army is the highest in rank; he remains in the middle, supported by elite and battle-hardened troops, which is why they are called the 'central strength' (zhongjian).) ) Wang Xun and Wang Yi's formations fell into chaos. Emperor Guangwu took advantage of the momentum to break their lines and successfully killed Wang Xun. The defenders within the city also burst forth with a thunderous roar of drums and shouts. Forces from within and without joined together, their cries shaking the very heavens and earth. Wang Mang's army suffered a catastrophic collapse; the fleeing soldiers trampled one another, and their bodies littered the ground for over a hundred li. (The character yi means to fall dead; it is pronounced yu-ji.) (It is sometimes written as ye.) ) A violent storm of thunder and wind suddenly erupted, sending roof tiles flying as rain poured down in torrents. The Zhi River overflowed its banks, (The Classic of Rivers states that the Zhi River originates from Mount Yao west of Luyang County in Nanyang, flows southeast past the north of Kunyang, and enters the Ru River to the east.) (The character zhi is pronounced zhi-li.) ) Even the tigers and leopards in the army trembled with fear. The fleeing soldiers struggled to cross the river, and so many tens of thousands drowned that their bodies choked the water and stopped its flow. (The number exceeded ten thousand, so they are counted in units of ten thousand.) ) Wang Yi, Yan You, and Chen Mao fled with their light cavalry, literally riding over the heaps of corpses to cross the river and escape. They captured the entire enemy supply train, including countless carriages, armor, and treasures. The quantity was so immense that it took months to haul it all away, and what remained was eventually set on fire.

å…‰æ­¦å› å¾©å¾‡ä¸‹æ½é™½ã€‚ ã€ˆç¸£åï¼Œå±¬æ½å·éƒ¡ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šè¨±å·ã€‚ ã€‰ æœƒä¼¯å‡ç‚ºæ›´å§‹æ‰€å®³ï¼Œå…‰æ­¦è‡ªçˆ¶åŸé¦³è©£å®›è¬ã€‚ ã€ˆçˆ¶åŸï¼Œç¸£ï¼Œå¤æ‡‰åœ‹ä¹Ÿï¼Œå±¬æ½å·éƒ¡ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šè¨±å·è‘‰ç¸£æ±åŒ—ã€‚ ä»¥ä¼¯å‡è¦‹å®³ï¼Œå¿ƒä¸è‡ªå®‰ï¼Œæ•…è¬ã€‚ ã€‰ å¸å¾’å®˜å±¬è¿å¼”å…‰æ­¦ï¼Œå…‰æ­¦é›£äº¤ç§èªï¼Œæ·±å¼•éè€Œå·²ã€‚ æœªç”è‡ªä¼æ˜†é™½ä¹‹åŠŸï¼Œåˆä¸æ•¢ç‚ºä¼¯å‡æœå–ªï¼Œé£²é£Ÿè¨€ç¬‘å¦‚å¹³å¸¸ã€‚ æ›´å§‹ä»¥æ˜¯æ…™ï¼Œæ‹œå…‰æ­¦ç‚ºç ´è™œå¤§å°‡è»ï¼Œå°æ­¦ä¿¡ä¾¯ã€‚
Emperor Guangwu then took advantage of the momentum to campaign and capture Yingyang. (Yingyang was a county belonging to the Yingchuan Commandery; its former city is in present-day Xuzhou.) ) Just then, Bosheng was murdered by Emperor Gengshi. Emperor Guangwu galloped from Fucheng to Wan to express his apologies and submission. (Fucheng was a county and the site of the ancient state of Ying, belonging to the Yingchuan Commandery; its former city is northeast of present-day Ye County in Xuzhou.) (Because Bosheng had been killed, Emperor Guangwu was deeply unsettled and thus went to offer his formal apologies.) ) The former subordinates of the Grand Minister over the Masses came to welcome and offer condolences to Emperor Guangwu, but he avoided any private conversation with them, instead taking all the blame upon himself. He never boasted of his achievements at Kunyang, nor did he dare to wear mourning clothes for Bosheng; he ate, drank, and conversed as if nothing were amiss. Emperor Gengshi, feeling ashamed because of this, appointed Emperor Guangwu as the Grand General for Crushing the Rebels and enfeoffed him as the Marquis of Wuxin.

ä¹æœˆåºšæˆŒï¼Œä¸‰è¼”è±ªæ¡€å…±èª…ç‹è½ï¼Œå‚³é¦–è©£å®›ã€‚ ã€ˆä¸‰è¼”è¬‚äº¬å…†ã€å·¦é¦®ç¿Šã€å³æ‰¶é¢¨ï¼Œå…±åœ¨é•·å®‰ä¸­ï¼Œåˆ†é ˜è«¸ç¸£ã€‚ æ·®å—å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ™ºéç™¾äººè¬‚ä¹‹è±ªã€‚ ã€ç™½è™é€šäº‘ï¼šã€Œè³¢è¬äººæ›°å‚‘ã€‚ ã€æ™‚åŸä¸­å°‘å¹´å­å¼Ÿå¼µé­šç­‰æ”»è½æ–¼æ¼¸è‡ºï¼Œå•†äººæœå³æ®ºè½ï¼Œæ ¡å°‰å…¬è³”å°±æ–¬è½é¦–ï¼Œå°‡è»ç”³å± å»ºç­‰å‚³è½é¦–è©£å®›ã€‚ ã€‰
On the gengxu day of the ninth month, the local heroes of the Sanfu region united to execute Wang Mang, and his head was sent to Wan. (The 'Sanfu' refers to the three capital districts of Jingzhao, Zuo Fengyi, and You Fufeng, which together administered the counties surrounding Chang'an.) (The Huainanzi states: "One whose intelligence exceeds that of a hundred men is called a hao (hero).") (The Baihu Tong states: "One whose virtue exceeds that of ten thousand men is called a jie (extraordinary talent).") (At that time, young men in the city, such as Zhang Yu and others, attacked Wang Mang at the Gradual Tower. A merchant named Du Wu killed Wang Mang, and Colonel Gongbin Jiu beheaded him. General Shentu Jian and others then sent Wang Mang's head to Wan.) )

æ›´å§‹å°‡åŒ—éƒ½æ´›é™½ï¼Œä»¥å…‰æ­¦è¡Œå¸éš·æ ¡å°‰ï¼Œä½¿å‰æ•´ä¿®å®®åºœã€‚ ã€ˆã€Šå‰æ›¸ã€‹æ›°ï¼šå¸éš·æ ¡å°‰æœ¬å‘¨å®˜ï¼Œæ­¦å¸åˆç½®ï¼ŒæŒç¯€ï¼Œå¾ä¸­éƒ½å®˜å¾’åƒäºŒç™¾äººï¼Œç£å¤§å§¦çŒ¾ã€‚ å¾Œç½·å…¶å…µï¼Œå¯Ÿä¸‰è¼”ã€ä¸‰æ²³ã€å¼˜è¾²ã€‚ ç§©æ¯”äºŒåƒçŸ³ã€‚ éŸ³ç¾©äº‘ï¼šã€Œä»¥æŒå¾’éš·è€Œå·¡å¯Ÿï¼Œæ•…æ›°å¸éš·ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ æ–¼æ˜¯ç½®åƒšå±¬ï¼Œä½œæ–‡ç§»ï¼Œ ã€ˆã€Šæ±è§€è¨˜ã€‹æ›°ã€Œæ–‡æ›¸ç§»èˆ‡å±¬ç¸£ã€ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ å¾äº‹å¸å¯Ÿï¼Œä¸€å¦‚èˆŠç« ã€‚ ã€ˆã€ŠçºŒæ¼¢æ›¸ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¸éš·ç½®å¾äº‹å²åäºŒäººï¼Œç§©çš†ç™¾çŸ³ï¼Œä¸»ç£ä¿ƒæ–‡æ›¸ï¼Œå¯Ÿèˆ‰éæ³•ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ æ™‚ä¸‰è¼”åå£«æ±è¿æ›´å§‹ï¼Œè¦‹è«¸å°‡éï¼Œçš†å† å¹˜ï¼Œ ã€ˆæ¼¢å®˜å„€æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¹˜è€…ï¼Œå¤ä¹‹å‘è³¤ä¸å† è€…ä¹‹æ‰€æœä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€æ–¹è¨€æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¦†é«»è¬‚ä¹‹å¹˜ï¼Œæˆ–è¬‚ä¹‹æ‰¿éœ²ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ è€Œæœå©¦äººè¡£ï¼Œè«¸äºç¹¡é•¼ï¼Œ ã€ˆã€Šå‰æ›¸ã€‹éŸ³ç¾©æ›°ï¼šã€Œè«¸äºï¼Œå¤§æ–è¡£ä¹Ÿï¼Œå¦‚å©¦äººä¹‹è¤‚è¡£ã€‚ ã€å­—æ›¸ç„¡ã€Œé•¼ã€å­—ï¼ŒçºŒæ¼¢æ›¸ä½œã€Œä˜¿ã€ï¼Œä¸¦éŸ³å…¶ç‰©åã€‚ æ¥Šé›„æ–¹è¨€æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¥œè¤•ï¼Œå…¶çŸ­è€…ï¼Œè‡ªé—œä¹‹è¥¿è¬‚ä¹‹ã€ä˜ªä˜¿ã€ã€‚ ã€éƒ­ç’æ³¨äº‘ï¼šã€Œä¿—åä˜¿æ–ã€‚ ã€æ“šæ­¤ï¼Œå³æ˜¯è«¸äºä¸ŠåŠ ç¹¡ä˜¿ï¼Œå¦‚ä»Šä¹‹åŠè‡‚ä¹Ÿã€‚ æˆ–ã€Œç¹¡ã€ä¸‹æœ‰ã€Œæ“ã€å­—ã€‚ ã€‰ è«ä¸ç¬‘ä¹‹ï¼Œæˆ–æœ‰ç•è€Œèµ°è€…ã€‚ ã€ˆã€ŠçºŒæ¼¢å¿—ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ™‚çŸ¥è€…è¦‹ä¹‹ï¼Œä»¥ç‚ºæœä¹‹ä¸ä¸­ï¼Œèº«ä¹‹ç½ä¹Ÿï¼Œä¹ƒå¥”å…¥é‚Šéƒ¡é¿ä¹‹ã€‚ æ˜¯æœå¦–ä¹Ÿã€‚ å…¶å¾Œæ›´å§‹é‚ç‚ºèµ¤çœ‰æ‰€æ®ºã€‚ ã€ã€‰ åŠè¦‹å¸éš·åƒšå±¬ï¼Œçš†æ­¡å–œä¸è‡ªå‹ã€‚ è€åæˆ–å‚æ¶•æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸åœ–ä»Šæ—¥å¾©è¦‹æ¼¢å®˜å¨å„€ï¼ ã€ç”±æ˜¯è­˜è€…çš†å±¬å¿ƒç„‰ã€‚
Emperor Gengshi, preparing to move his capital north to Luoyang, appointed Emperor Guangwu as the Acting Colonel-Director of Retainers and sent him ahead to renovate the imperial palaces and government offices. (The Book of Han states: The office of Colonel-Director of Retainers was originally a Zhou position. Emperor Wu first re-established it, granting the officer the imperial tally and a force of 1,200 subordinates from the capital to oversee and apprehend major criminals.) (Later, the military force was disbanded, and the office was tasked with inspecting the Sanfu region, the three commanderies of the Yellow River, and Hongnong.) (The salary rank was equivalent to two thousand piculs.) (The Phonetics and Meanings states: "Because the office managed retinue and conducted patrols and inspections, it was called Sili (Director of Retainers).") ) Thereupon, he appointed his staff and issued official written instructions, (The Records of the Eastern Tower states this refers to "the distribution of official documents to the subordinate counties.") ) and carried out administrative inspections exactly according to the established protocols of the former Han dynasty. (The Continued Book of Han states: "The Colonel-Director of Retainers appointed twelve Assistant Secretaries, each with a salary rank of one hundred piculs, who were responsible for managing official documents and investigating and reporting illegal acts.") ) At that time, the officials and soldiers of the Sanfu region traveled east to welcome Emperor Gengshi. When they saw the various generals passing by, they were all wearing headcloths, (The Ceremonial Protocols of Han Officials states: "The headcloth (ze) was originally worn by those of low status who were not entitled to wear formal caps.") (The Dialects states: "That which covers the hair knot is called a ze, or sometimes a 'dew-catcher'.") ) but they were dressed in women's clothingâ€”zhuyu robes with embroidered short sleeves. (The Book of Han: Phonetics and Meanings states: "The zhuyu was a large side-slit garment, similar to a woman's outer robe.") (The character é•¼ is not found in dictionaries; the Continued Book of Han writes it as ä˜¿; both are pronounced qi-wu.) (Yang Xiong's Dialects states: "Short chanyu robes are called chongjue in the regions west of the pass.") (Guo Pu's commentary states: "The common name is jueye.") (Based on this, it refers to an embroidered short-sleeved jacket worn over a zhuyu robe, similar to the 'half-sleeve' garments of today.) (In some versions, the character yong (embrace) appears after 'embroidered'.) ) No one could help but laugh at them, while some were so unsettled by the sight that they actually fled in fear. (The Continued Han Treatises states: "Those who were knowledgeable saw this and believed that such inappropriate attire was a sign of impending disaster for the individuals wearing it; consequently, they fled to the border commanderies to avoid them.") ("These were regarded as 'portents of attire' (fuyao).") ("Later, Emperor Gengshi was indeed killed by the Red Eyebrows.") ) When they saw the subordinates of the Colonel-Director of Retainers, however, they were all overjoyed beyond measure. Some of the elderly officials shed tears and exclaimed, "I never imagined that I would live to see the dignified appearance of Han officials once again!" From that moment on, all those with foresight gave their loyalty to him.

åŠæ›´å§‹è‡³æ´›é™½ï¼Œä¹ƒé£å…‰æ­¦ä»¥ç ´è™œå°‡è»è¡Œå¤§å¸é¦¬äº‹ã€‚ åæœˆï¼ŒæŒç¯€åŒ—åº¦æ²³ï¼Œ ã€ˆæ¼¢å®˜å„€æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤ªå°‰ï¼Œç§¦å®˜ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ­¦å¸æ›´åå¤§å¸é¦¬ã€‚ ã€ç¯€ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ç‚ºä¿¡ä¹Ÿï¼Œä»¥ç«¹ç‚ºä¹‹ï¼ŒæŸ„é•·å…«å°ºï¼Œä»¥æ—„ç‰›å°¾ç‚ºå…¶çœŠä¸‰é‡ã€‚ é¦®è¡èˆ‡ç”°é‚‘æ›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šä»¥ä¸€ç¯€ä¹‹ä»»ï¼Œå»ºä¸‰è»ä¹‹å¨ï¼Œè±ˆç‰¹å¯µå…¶å…«å°ºä¹‹ç«¹ï¼ŒçŠ›ç‰›ä¹‹å°¾å“‰ï¼ ã€ã€ŠçºŒæ¼¢å¿—ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ›´å§‹æ™‚ï¼Œå—æ–¹æœ‰ç«¥è¬ äº‘ï¼šã€è«§ä¸è«§ï¼Œåœ¨èµ¤çœ‰ï¼› å¾—ä¸å¾—ï¼Œåœ¨æ²³åŒ—ã€‚ ã€å¾Œæ›´å§‹ç‚ºèµ¤çœ‰æ‰€æ®ºï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸è«§ä¹Ÿï¼› å…‰æ­¦ç”±æ²³åŒ—è€Œèˆˆï¼Œæ˜¯å¾—ä¹‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€ã€‰ é®æ…°å·éƒ¡ã€‚ æ‰€åˆ°éƒ¨ç¸£ï¼Œè¼’è¦‹äºŒåƒçŸ³ã€é•·åã€ä¸‰è€ã€å®˜å±¬ï¼Œä¸‹è‡³ä½å²ï¼Œ ã€ˆäºŒåƒç™¾è¬‚éƒ¡å®ˆä¹Ÿã€‚ é•·åè¬‚ç¸£ä»¤é•·åŠä¸å°‰ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¸‰è€è€…ï¼Œéƒ·å®˜ä¹Ÿã€‚ é«˜ç¥–ç½®ã€‚ ã€Šå‰æ›¸ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œèˆ‰äººå¹´äº”åå·²ä¸Šï¼Œæœ‰ä¿®è¡Œèƒ½å¸¥è¡†è€…ï¼Œç½®ä»¥ç‚ºä¸‰è€ï¼Œæ¯éƒ·ä¸€äººï¼› æ“‡éƒ·ä¸‰è€ç‚ºç¸£ä¸‰è€ï¼Œèˆ‡ä»¤é•·ä¸å°‰ä»¥äº‹ç›¸æ•ï¼Œå¾©å…¶å‚œæˆã€‚ ã€ã€ŠçºŒæ¼¢å¿—ã€‹æ›°ã€Œæ¯åˆºå²çš†æœ‰å¾äº‹å²ã€å‡ä½ï¼Œæ¯ç¸£å„ç½®è«¸äº‹æ›¹å²ã€ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ è€ƒå¯Ÿé»œé™Ÿï¼Œå¦‚å·ç‰§è¡Œéƒ¨äº‹ã€‚ ã€ˆæ¼¢åˆé£ä¸ç›¸å²åˆ†åˆºå·ï¼Œæ­¦å¸æ”¹ç½®åˆºå²ï¼Œå¯Ÿå·ï¼Œç§©å…­ç™¾çŸ³ã€‚ æˆå¸æ›´åç‰§ï¼Œç§©äºŒåƒçŸ³ã€‚ æ¼¢å®˜å…¸å„€æ›°ã€Œåˆºå²è¡Œéƒ¡åœ‹ï¼Œçœå¯Ÿæ”¿æ•ï¼Œé»œé™Ÿèƒ½ä¸ï¼Œæ–·ç†å†¤ç„ã€ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ è¼’å¹³é£å›šå¾’ï¼Œé™¤ç‹è½è‹›æ”¿ï¼Œ ã€ˆã€Šèªªæ–‡ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‹›ï¼Œå°è‰ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€è¨€æ”¿ä»¤ç¹ç´°ã€‚ ç¦®è¨˜æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‹›æ”¿çŒ›æ–¼è™ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ å¾©æ¼¢å®˜åã€‚ åäººå–œæ±ï¼Œçˆ­æŒç‰›é…’è¿å‹ã€‚
When Emperor Gengshi reached Luoyang, he dispatched Emperor Guangwu as the General for Crushing the Rebels to serve as the Acting Grand Minister of War. In the tenth month, bearing the imperial tally, he crossed the Yellow River to the north. (The Ceremonial Protocols of Han Officials states: "The Grand Commandant was an office established during the Qin; Emperor Wu changed the title to 'Grand Minister of War'.") (The imperial tally (jie) served as a token of trust. It was made of bamboo with a handle eight feet long, and its head was adorned with three layers of tassels made from yak tails.) (Feng Yan wrote in a letter to Tian Yi: "Now, with the authority granted by a single tally, one can establish the majesty of the three armies. Is it only the eight-foot bamboo and the yak tail that are being honored?") (The Continued Han Treatises state: "During the reign of Emperor Gengshi, there was a children's nursery rhyme in the south that went: 'Whether things go well or not depends on the Red Eyebrows;") "Whether success is attained or not depends on Hebei.'") (Later, Emperor Gengshi was indeed killed by the Red Eyebrows, which fulfilled the 'not going well' part;) (and Emperor Guangwu rose to power from Hebei, which fulfilled the 'attaining success' part.) ) He stabilized and reassured the various provinces and commanderies. Wherever he traveled through the various counties and districts, he would always grant audiences to the local officialsâ€”including the Grand Administrators (two thousand picul officials), the county magistrates, the local elders, and their subordinates, down to the lowest-ranking assistants. (The term 'two thousand piculs' refers to the Grand Administrator of a commandery.) (The 'chief officials' refer to the county magistrates and their assistants and commandants.) (The 'Three Elders' were officials at the township level.) (The position was established by Emperor Gaozu.) (The Book of Han states: "Men over the age of fifty who are of good character and capable of leading the people are to be appointed as 'Three Elders,' with one for each township;") "From among the township Three Elders, one is chosen to be the county Three Elder, who consults with the magistrate and his assistants on local affairs and is exempted from labor and military service.") (The Continued Book of Han states: "Each Regional Inspector is assisted by Assistant Secretaries and various deputies, and each county maintains secretaries for various administrative departments.") ) He evaluated the performance of officials, demoting or promoting them, just as a provincial governor would do while making his rounds. (At the beginning of the Han dynasty, secretaries from the Chancellor's office were sent to inspect the provinces. Emperor Wu changed this, establishing the office of Regional Inspector with a salary rank of six hundred piculs to oversee the provinces.) (Emperor Cheng changed the title to 'Governor' (mu), with a salary rank of two thousand piculs.) (The Protocols of Han Officials states: "The Regional Inspector travels through the commanderies and principalities to oversee the administration and education of the people, promote the capable and demote the incompetent, and resolve cases of judicial injustice.") ) He consistently reviewed and released prisoners fairly and abolished the oppressive policies of Wang Mang's administration. (The Shuowen Jiezi states: "Ke refers to small grasses.") (This is used here to describe government orders that are excessively numerous and detailed.) (The Book of Rites states: "An oppressive government is more fearsome than a tiger.") ) He restored the official titles of the Han dynasty. The officials and common people were overjoyed, and they vied with one another to welcome him with gifts of oxen and wine.
12
é€²è‡³é‚¯é„²ï¼Œ ã€ˆç¸£åï¼Œå±¬è¶™åœ‹ï¼Œä»Šæ´ºå·ç¸£ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€Šå‰æ›¸ã€‹éŸ³ç¾©ï¼šã€Œé‚¯ï¼Œå±±åï¼› é„²ï¼Œç›¡ä¹Ÿã€‚ é‚¯å±±è‡³æ­¤è€Œç›¡ã€‚ åŸéƒ­å­—çš†å¾é‚‘ï¼Œå› ä»¥åç„‰ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ æ•…è¶™ç¹†ç‹å­æ— ã€ˆç¹†ç‹ï¼Œæ™¯å¸ä¸ƒä»£å­«ï¼Œåå…ƒã€‚ ã€Šå‰æ›¸ã€‹æ›°ï¼Œå…ƒåæ®ºäººï¼Œç‚ºå¤§é´»è‡šæ‰€å¥ã€‚ è¬šæ›°ç¹†ï¼ŒéŸ³è¬¬ã€‚ ã€Šæ±è§€è¨˜ã€‹æ›°ã€Œæ—ã€ä½œã€Œè‡¨ã€å­—ã€‚ ã€‰ èªªå…‰æ­¦æ›°ï¼šã€Œèµ¤çœ‰ä»Šåœ¨æ²³æ±ï¼Œä½†æ±ºæ°´çŒä¹‹ï¼Œç™¾è¬ä¹‹è¡†å¯ä½¿ç‚ºé­šã€‚ã€ ã€ˆèµ¤çœ‰è³Šå¸¥æ¨Šå´‡ç­‰æå…¶è¡†èˆ‡ç‹è½å…µäº‚ï¼Œçš†æœ±å…¶çœ‰ä»¥ç›¸åˆ¥ï¼Œæ•…æ›°èµ¤çœ‰ã€‚ ã€ŠçºŒæ¼¢æ›¸ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ˜¯æ™‚ä¸Šå¹³æ²³åŒ—ï¼Œéé‚¯é„²ï¼Œæ—é€²è¦‹ï¼Œè¨€èµ¤çœ‰å¯ç ´ã€‚ ä¸Šå•å…¶æ•…ï¼Œå°æ›°ï¼šã€æ²³æ°´å¾åˆ—äººåŒ—æµï¼› å¦‚æ±ºæ²³æ°´çŒä¹‹ï¼Œçš†å¯ä»¤ç‚ºé­šã€‚ ã€ä¸Šä¸ç„¶ä¹‹ã€‚ ã€åˆ—äººï¼Œç¸£ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šæ´ºå·è‚¥éƒ·ç¸£æ±åŒ—ã€‚ ã€‰ å…‰æ­¦ä¸è…ï¼Œå»ä¹‹çœŸå®šã€‚ ã€ˆç¸£åï¼Œå±¬çœŸå®šåœ‹ï¼Œä»Šæ’å·ç¸£ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ æ—æ–¼æ˜¯ä¹ƒè©ä»¥åœè€…ç‹éƒç‚ºæˆå¸å­å­è¼¿ï¼Œ ã€ˆã€Šå‰æ›¸ã€‹æ›°ï¼Œç«‹åœ‹å°‡è»å­«å»ºå¥äº‘ã€Œä¸çŸ¥ä½•ä¸€ç”·å­é®è‡£è»Šå‰ï¼Œè‡ªç¨±æ¼¢æ°åŠ‰å­è¼¿ï¼Œæˆå¸ä¸‹å¦»å­ä¹Ÿï¼ŒåŠ‰æ°ç•¶å¾©ã€ã€‚ æ•…éƒå› è€Œç¨±ä¹‹ã€‚ ã€‰ åäºŒæœˆï¼Œç«‹éƒç‚ºå¤©å­ï¼Œéƒ½é‚¯é„²ï¼Œé‚é£ä½¿è€…é™ä¸‹éƒ¡åœ‹ã€‚
He advanced as far as Handan. (Handan was a county belonging to the State of Zhao; it is now part of Mingzhou.) (The Book of Han: Phonetics and Meanings states: "Han is the name of a mountain;") ("Dan means to come to an end.") ("The Han Mountains come to an end at this location.") ("Since characters related to city walls often contain the city radical, this place was named accordingly.") ) Liu Lin, the son of the late King Mu of Zhao, (King Mu, whose name was Liu Yuan, was a seventh-generation descendant of Emperor Jing.) (The Book of Han states that Liu Yuan was impeached by the Grand Herald for committing murder.) (His posthumous name was Mu; the character is pronounced miu.) (The Records of the Eastern Tower writes his name with the character lin meaning 'approaching.') ) came to persuade Emperor Guangwu, saying: "The Red Eyebrows are currently in Hedong. If we simply breach the dikes and flood them, we can turn their million-strong army into fish." (The bandit leader Fan Chong and others, fearing that their followers would be confused with Wang Mang's troops in battle, had everyone paint their eyebrows vermilion to distinguish themselves; thus they were called the 'Red Eyebrows.') (The Continued Book of Han states: "At that time, as the Emperor was pacifying Hebei and passing through Handan, Liu Lin came to see him and claimed the Red Eyebrows could be defeated.) (The Emperor asked how, and he replied: 'The Yellow River flows north from Lieren;) (if we breach the river and flood them, they will all be turned into fish.') (The Emperor did not agree with his suggestion.) (Lieren was a county; its former city is located northeast of present-day Feixiang County in Mingzhou.) ) Emperor Guangwu did not respond and left for Zhending. (Zhending was a county belonging to the Principality of Zhending; it is now part of Hengzhou.) ) Thereupon, Liu Lin falsely claimed that a diviner named Wang Lang was actually Liu Ziyu, the son of Emperor Cheng. (The Book of Han states that Sun Jian, the General for Establishing the State, memorialized the throne, saying: "An unknown man blocked my carriage and claimed to be Liu Ziyu of the Han imperial clan, a son of Emperor Cheng born to a concubine, and asserted that the Liu clan should be restored to power.") (Therefore, Wang Lang adopted this identity for himself.) ) In the twelfth month, Wang Lang was established as the Emperor, with his capital at Handan. He then dispatched messengers to demand the surrender of the various commanderies and principalities.

ã€ˆã€Šå±±æµ·ç¶“ã€‹äº‘ï¼šã€Œå¤ªæˆ²ä¹‹å±±ï¼Œæ»¹æ²±ä¹‹æ°´å‡ºç„‰ã€‚ ã€åœ¨ä»Šä»£å·ç¹ç•¤ç¸£æ±ï¼Œæµç¶“å®šå·æ·±æ¾¤ç¸£æ±å—ï¼Œå³å…‰æ­¦æ‰€åº¦è™•ï¼Œä»Šä¿—çŒ¶è¬‚ä¹‹å±åº¦å£ã€‚ ã€ˆã€ŠçºŒæ¼¢æ›¸ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ™‚å†°æ»‘é¦¬åƒµï¼Œä¹ƒå„ä»¥å›Šç››æ²™ï¼Œå¸ƒå†°ä¸Šåº¦ç„‰ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ æœªç•¢æ•¸è»Šè€Œé™·ã€‚ é€²è‡³ä¸‹åšåŸè¥¿ï¼Œ ã€ˆä¸‹åšï¼Œç¸£ï¼Œå±¬ä¿¡éƒ½åœ‹ã€‚ åœ¨åšæ°´ä¹‹ä¸‹ï¼Œæ•…æ›°ä¸‹åšã€‚ ã€ˆä¿¡éƒ½éƒ¡ï¼Œä»Šå…¾å·ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ å…‰æ­¦å³é¦³èµ´ä¹‹ï¼Œä¿¡éƒ½å¤ªå®ˆä»»å…‰é–‹é–€å‡ºè¿ã€‚ ä¸–ç¥–å› ç™¼æ—ç¸£ï¼Œå¾—å››åƒäººï¼Œå…ˆæ“Šå ‚é™½ã€è²°ç¸£ï¼Œçš†é™ä¹‹ã€‚ ã€ˆå ‚é™½åŠè²°ä¸¦å±¬é‰…é¹¿éƒ¡ã€‚ ã€å’æ­£ï¼Œè·å¦‚å¤ªå®ˆã€‚ ã€‰ åˆæ˜ŒåŸäººåŠ‰æ¤ï¼Œå®‹å­äººè€¿ç´”ï¼Œ ã€ˆæ˜ŒåŸï¼Œç¸£ï¼Œå±¬ä¿¡éƒ½åœ‹ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šå…¾å·è¥¿åŒ—ã€‚ å®‹å­ï¼Œç¸£ï¼Œå±¬é‰…é¹¿éƒ¡ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šè¶™å·å¹³æ£˜ç¸£åŒ—ã€‚ ã€‰ å„ç‡å®—è¦ªå­å¼Ÿï¼Œæ“šå…¶ç¸£é‚‘ï¼Œä»¥å¥‰å…‰æ­¦ã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯åŒ—é™ä¸‹æ›²é™½ï¼Œ ã€ˆç¸£åï¼Œå±¬é‰…é¹¿éƒ¡ã€‚ å¸¸å±±éƒ¡æœ‰ä¸Šæ›²é™½ï¼Œæ•…æ­¤è¨€ä¸‹ã€‚ ã€‰ è¡†ç¨åˆï¼Œæ¨‚é™„è€…è‡³æœ‰æ•¸è¬äººã€‚
In the first month of the second year, seeing that Wang Lang's power was rapidly growing, Emperor Guangwu campaigned north to Ji. (Ji was a county belonging to the Zhuo Commandery; it is now part of Youzhou.) (The original character for Ji is composed of the radicals for 'contract' and 'city,' as seen in the Shuowen Jiezi.) ) Wang Lang issued a manifesto offering a reward of ten thousand households for the capture of Emperor Guangwu. (The Shuowen Jiezi states: "A xi (manifesto) is a document written on wooden tablets, twelve inches in length.") ("It is called a xi and is used for official summons.") (It also states: "Offering wealth to obtain something is called gou (a reward).") (Cao Cao, known posthumously as Emperor Wu of Wei, stated in a memorial: "In cases of extreme urgency, chicken feathers are inserted into the document, which is then called a 'feathered manifesto' (yuxi).") ) Meanwhile, Liu Jie, the son of the late King of Guangyang, (The King of Guangyang was named Liu Jia, a fifth-generation descendant of Emperor Wu.) ) rose in rebellion in Ji to support Wang Lang. The city fell into chaos as rumors spread rapidly, with people claiming that a messenger from Handan had just arrived. All the local officials, from the Grand Administrator on down, went out to welcome him. Thereupon, Emperor Guangwu hurried to turn his carriage southward. (The character qu means urgent; it is pronounced cu.) ) Traveling day and night, he did not dare to enter any cities or towns, instead choosing to camp and eat by the side of the road. When they reached Raoyang, (Raoyang was a county belonging to the Principality of Anping, located on the north bank of the Rao River; its former city is northeast of present-day Raoyang County in Yingzhou.) ) his staff and attendants were all completely out of food. Emperor Guangwu then identified himself as a messenger from Handan and entered the local relay station. (It refers to a guest house or relay station.) (The character chuan is pronounced zhuan; this applies hereafter.) ) Just as the relay station officials were serving food, Emperor Guangwu's attendants, who were famished, began to fight over and snatch the food. Suspecting that the group was a fraud, the relay station officials beat their drums dozens of times, (The character chui is pronounced zhui.) ) and deceitfully shouted that a general from Handan had arrived. (The character dai means to deceive or trick; it is pronounced dai.) ) All of Emperor Guangwu's staff turned pale with fear. Emperor Guangwu climbed into his carriage and prepared to gallop away; but then, fearing he could not escape, he slowly sat back down and said, "Please, invite the general from Handan in." After a long pause, he finally drove away. Someone within the relay station called out to the gatekeepers from a distance to close the gates. The head of the gate said, "In such uncertain times, how can we know what will happen? Why should we shut out a man of such distinction?" Thus, they were able to exit through the south gate. Traveling day and night, they braved the biting frost and snow. (The character meng means to brave or face.) ) The weather was so bitterly cold that their faces became raw and cracked. When they reached the Hutuo River, (The Classic of Mountains and Seas states: "The Hutuo River originates from Mount Taixi.") (Mount Taixi is located east of present-day Fanshi County in Daizhou. The river flows southeast past Shenze County in Dingzhou, which is where Emperor Guangwu crossed; even today, locals still refer to that spot as the "Dangerous Crossing.") (Commentary by your servant, [Li] Xian: The Hutuo River used to be south of Raoyang, but during the time of Cao Cao, Emperor Taizu of Wei, the old Rao River channel burst, and he ordered the river to be diverted northward into the "New Ditch"; consequently, the river is now located north of Raoyang County.) ) There were no boats available, but it just so happened that the river had frozen over, allowing them to cross. (The Continued Book of Han states: "At that time, the ice was so slippery that the horses were stiff with fear; consequently, they filled bags with sand and spread it over the ice so they could cross.") ) Just as the last few carriages were crossing, the ice gave way and they sank. They advanced until they reached the west of Xiabo City, (Xiabo was a county belonging to the Principality of Xindu.) (It was named Xiabo because it was situated downstream from the Bo River.) (The former city is located south of present-day Xiabo County in Jizhou.) ) and they were so alarmed and confused that they did not know which way to go. An old man dressed in white was by the side of the road, (The old man was likely a divine being; even today, there is still a shrine dedicated to him west of Xiabo County.) ) He pointed the way and said, "Press on! Xindu Commandery is still holding out for the central government in Chang'an, and it is only eighty li from here." (Xindu Commandery is present-day Jizhou.) ) Emperor Guangwu immediately galloped toward it, and Ren Guang, the Grand Administrator of Xindu, opened the gates and came out to welcome him. Emperor Guangwu then mobilized troops from the neighboring counties, raising four thousand men. He first attacked the counties of Tangyang and Shi, both of which surrendered to him. (Tangyang and Shi both belonged to Julu Commandery.) (Tangyang was located on the north bank of the Tang River; it is a county in present-day Jizhou, and its former city is southwest of Lucheng County in Jizhou.) (The character shi [in the name of Shi County] is pronounced shi.) ) Pi Tong, the Grand Administrator (muzheng) of Herong under Wang Mang, also surrendered the entire commandery. (The Records of the Eastern Pavilion states: "Wang Mang divided Julu into Hecheng Commandery.") (The title muzheng was equivalent in rank to a Grand Administrator.) ) Additionally, Liu Zhi of Changcheng and Geng Chun of Songzi, (Changcheng was a county belonging to the Principality of Xindu; its former city is northwest of present-day Jizhou.) (Songzi was a county belonging to Julu Commandery; its former city is north of present-day Pingji County in Zhaozhou.) ) each led their clansmen and younger relatives to occupy their respective counties and towns in service to Emperor Guangwu. Thereupon, he moved north and accepted the surrender of Xiaquyang, (Xiaquyang was a county belonging to Julu Commandery.) (Since Changshan Commandery had a county named Shangquyang [Upper Quyang], this one is referred to as Xiaquyang [Lower Quyang].) ) His forces gradually gathered, and those who were eager to join him eventually numbered in the tens of thousands.
14
å¾©åŒ—æ“Šä¸­å±±ï¼Œ ã€ˆä¸­å±±ï¼Œåœ‹ï¼Œä¸€åä¸­äººäº­ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šå®šå·å”ç¸£æ±åŒ—ã€‚ å¼µæ›œä¸­å±±è¨˜æ›°ï¼šã€ŒåŸä¸­æœ‰å±±ï¼Œæ•…æ›°ä¸­å±±ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ æ‹”ç›§å¥´ã€‚ ã€ˆç¸£åï¼Œå±¬ä¸­å±±åœ‹ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šå®šå·å®‰å–œç¸£ã€‚ æ°´ç¶“æ³¨æ›°ï¼šã€Œç¸£æœ‰é»‘æ°´æ•…æ± ï¼Œæ°´é»‘æ›°ç›§ï¼Œä¸æµæ›°å¥´ï¼Œå› ä»¥ç‚ºåã€‚ ã€ã€‰ æ‰€éç™¼å¥”å‘½å…µï¼Œ ã€ˆã€Šå‰æ›¸ã€‹éŸ³ç¾©æ›°ï¼šã€ŒèˆŠæ™‚éƒ¡åœ‹çš†æœ‰æå®˜ã€é¨å£«ï¼Œè‹¥æœ‰æ€¥é›£ï¼Œæ¬Šå–é©å‹‡è€…èå‘½å¥”èµ´ï¼Œæ•…è¬‚ä¹‹ã€å¥”å‘½ã€ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ ç§»æª„é‚Šéƒ¨ï¼Œå…±æ“Šé‚¯é„²ï¼Œéƒ¡ç¸£é‚„å¾©éŸ¿æ‡‰ã€‚ å—æ“Šæ–°å¸‚ã€çœŸå®šã€å…ƒæ°ã€é˜²å­ï¼Œçš†ä¸‹ä¹‹ï¼Œ ã€ˆæ–°å¸‚ï¼Œç¸£ï¼Œå±¬é‰…é¹¿éƒ¡ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šæ’å·æ±åŒ—ã€‚ å…ƒæ°ã€æˆ¿å­ï¼Œå±¬å¸¸å±±éƒ¡ï¼Œä¸¦ä»Šè¶™å·ç¸£ä¹Ÿã€‚ é˜²èˆ‡æˆ¿å¤å­—é€šç”¨ã€‚ ã€‰ å› å…¥è¶™ç•Œã€‚
He again struck northward to attack Zhongshan, (Zhongshan was a Principality, also known as Zhongren Pavilion; its former city is located northeast of present-day Tang County in Dingzhou.) (Zhang Yao's Records of Zhongshan states: "There is a mountain within the city, which is why it is called Zhongshan [Middle Mountain].") ) and captured Lunu. (Lunu was a county belonging to the Principality of Zhongshan; its former city is in present-day Anxi County in Dingzhou.) (The Commentary on the Water Classic states: "The county contains the ancient Black Water Pond; since black water is called lu and stagnant water is called nu, it was named accordingly.") ) Wherever he went, he mobilized the "emergency response" (benming) troops, (The Notes on the Pronunciation and Meaning of the History of the Former Han states: "In former times, the commanderies and principalities all maintained skilled infantry and cavalry; in times of extreme urgency, the most valiant men were temporarily recruited to respond immediately upon receiving orders, which is why they were called 'those who run to their orders' (benming).") ) He issued manifestos to the border regions, calling for a joint attack on Handan, and the various commanderies and counties once again responded with support. Moving south, he attacked Xinshi, Zhending, Yuanshi, and Fangzi, and forced them all to surrender. (Xinshi was a county belonging to Julu Commandery; its former city is northeast of present-day Hengzhou.) (Yuanshi and Fangzi belonged to Changshan Commandery; both are counties in present-day Zhaozhou.) (The character fang [in Fangzi] was used interchangeably with the character fang [house] in ancient times.) ) He then entered the territory of the Principality of Zhao.
15
æ™‚ç‹éƒå¤§å°‡æè‚²å±¯æŸäººï¼Œ ã€ˆç¸£åï¼Œå±¬è¶™åœ‹ï¼Œä»Šé‚¢å·ç¸£ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ç¸£ä¹‹è¥¿åŒ—ã€‚ ã€‰ æ¼¢å…µä¸çŸ¥è€Œé€²ï¼Œå‰éƒ¨åå°‡æœ±æµ®ã€é„§ç¦¹ç‚ºè‚²æ‰€ç ´ï¼Œäº¡å¤±è¼œé‡ã€‚ å…‰æ­¦åœ¨å¾Œèä¹‹ï¼Œæ”¶æµ®ã€ç¦¹æ•£å’ï¼Œèˆ‡è‚²æˆ°æ–¼éƒ­é–€ï¼Œå¤§ç ´ä¹‹ï¼Œç›¡å¾—å…¶æ‰€ç²ã€‚ è‚²é‚„ä¿åŸï¼Œæ”»ä¹‹ä¸ä¸‹ï¼Œæ–¼æ˜¯å¼•å…µæ‹”å»£é˜¿ã€‚ ã€ˆç¸£åï¼Œå±¬é‰…é¹¿éƒ¡ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šè¶™å·è±¡åŸç¸£è¥¿åŒ—ã€‚ ã€‰ æœƒä¸Šè°·å¤ªå®ˆè€¿æ³ã€æ¼é™½å¤ªå®ˆå½­å¯µ ã€ˆä¸Šè°·ï¼Œéƒ¡ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šåª¯å·æ‡·æˆç¸£ã€‚ æ¼é™½ï¼Œéƒ¡ï¼Œåœ¨æ¼æ°´ä¹‹é™½ï¼Œä»Šå¹½å·ç¸£ã€‚ ã€‰ å„é£å…¶å°‡å³æ¼¢ã€å¯‡æ‚ç­‰å°‡çªé¨ä¾†åŠ©æ“Šç‹éƒï¼Œ ã€ˆçªé¨ï¼Œè¨€èƒ½è¡çªè»é™£ã€‚ ã€‰ æ›´å§‹äº¦é£å°šæ›¸åƒ•å°„è¬èº¬è¨éƒï¼Œ ã€ˆæ¼¢å®˜å„€æ›°ï¼šã€Œå°šæ›¸å››å“¡ï¼Œæ­¦å¸ç½®ï¼Œæˆå¸åŠ ä¸€ç‚ºäº”ã€‚ æœ‰å¸¸ä¾æ›¹å°šæ›¸ï¼Œä¸»ä¸ç›¸å¾¡å²äº‹ï¼› äºŒåƒçŸ³å°šæ›¸ï¼Œä¸»åˆºå²ã€äºŒåƒçŸ³äº‹ï¼› æˆ¶æ›¹å°šæ›¸ï¼Œä¸»äººåº¶ä¸Šæ›¸äº‹ï¼› ä¸»å®¢å°šæ›¸ï¼Œä¸»å¤–åœ‹å››å¤·äº‹ï¼› æˆå¸åŠ ä¸‰å…¬å°šæ›¸ï¼Œä¸»æ–·ç„äº‹ã€‚ åƒ•å°„ï¼Œç§¦å®˜ä¹Ÿã€‚ åƒ•ï¼Œä¸»ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤è€…é‡æ­¦äº‹ï¼Œæ¯å®˜å¿…æœ‰ä¸»å°„ä»¥ç£èª²ä¹‹ã€‚ ã€è¬èº¬ç‚ºå°šæ›¸åƒ•å°„ã€‚ ã€‰ å…‰æ­¦å› å¤§é¥—å£«å’ï¼Œé‚æ±åœé‰…é¹¿ã€‚ ç‹éƒå®ˆå°‡ç‹é¥’å …å®ˆï¼Œæœˆé¤˜ä¸ä¸‹ã€‚ éƒé£å°‡å€ªå®ã€åŠ‰å¥‰ ã€ˆå€ªéŸ³äº”å…®åã€‚ ã€‰ ç‡æ•¸è¬äººæ•‘é‰…é¹¿ï¼Œå…‰æ­¦é€†æˆ°æ–¼å—äœŒï¼Œ ã€ˆç¸£åï¼Œå±¬é‰…é¹¿éƒ¡ï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šé‚¢å·æŸäººç¸£æ±åŒ—ã€‚ å·¦å‚³é½Šåœ‹å¤ä¼æ™‰å–æ¬’ï¼Œå³å…¶åœ°ä¹Ÿã€‚ å…¶å¾Œå—å¾™ï¼Œæ•…åŠ ã€Œå—ã€ã€‚ ä»Šä¿—è¬‚ä¹‹å€«åŸï¼Œè²ä¹‹è½‰ä¹Ÿã€‚ äœŒéŸ³åŠ›å…¨åã€‚ ã€‰ æ–¬é¦–æ•¸åƒç´šã€‚ å››æœˆï¼Œé€²åœé‚¯é„²ï¼Œé€£æˆ°ç ´ä¹‹ã€‚ äº”æœˆç”²è¾°ï¼Œæ‹”å…¶åŸï¼Œèª…ç‹éƒã€‚ æ”¶æ–‡æ›¸ï¼Œå¾—åäººèˆ‡éƒäº¤é—œè¬—æ¯€è€…æ•¸åƒç« ã€‚ å…‰æ­¦ä¸çœï¼Œæœƒè«¸å°‡è»ç‡’ä¹‹ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œä»¤åå´å­è‡ªå®‰ã€‚ã€ ã€ˆåå´ï¼Œä¸å®‰ä¹Ÿã€‚ è©©åœ‹é¢¨æ›°ï¼šã€Œå±•è½‰åå´ã€‚ ã€ã€‰
At that time, Wang Lang's grand general Li Yu was stationed at Bairen. (Bairen was a county belonging to the Principality of Zhao; it is in present-day Xingzhou, and its former city is northwest of the current county seat.) ) The Han troops advanced without being aware of the situation, and the generals of the vanguard, Zhu Fu and Deng Yu, were defeated by Li Yu, losing their entire supply train in the process. When Emperor Guangwu heard of this from the rear, he collected the scattered troops of Zhu Fu and Deng Yu and engaged Li Yu at the outer city gates. He decisively defeated Li Yu and recovered all the supplies that had been captured. Li Yu retreated to defend the city, and since Emperor Guangwu could not capture it immediately, he led his troops instead to capture Guang'e. (Guang'e was a county belonging to Julu Commandery; its former city is northwest of present-day Xiangcheng County in Zhaozhou.) ) It so happened that Geng Kuang, the Grand Administrator of Shanggu, and Peng Chong, the Grand Administrator of Yuyang, (Shanggu was a commandery; its former city is in present-day Huairong County in Guizhou.) (Yuyang Commandery was located on the north bank of the Yu River; it is present-day Youzhou County.) ) They each sent their generals, including Wu Han and Kou Xun, leading their elite "assault cavalry" (tuqi) to assist in the attack against Wang Lang. (The term tuqi [assault cavalry] refers to cavalry capable of charging into and breaking enemy formations.) ) Emperor Gengshi also dispatched the Supervisor of the Secretariat (shangshu puye) Xie Gong to suppress Wang Lang. (The Ceremonies of Han Officials states: "The Secretariat (shangshu) consisted of four members, established by Emperor Wu; Emperor Cheng added one more, making five.") (The Director of the Imperial Attendants Bureau supervised matters related to the Chancellor and the Censor-in-Chief.) (The Director of the Two-Thousand-Picul Bureau supervised matters related to Provincial Inspectors and officials with a two-thousand-picul rank.) (The Director of the Household Bureau supervised memorials submitted by the common people.) (The Director of the Reception Bureau supervised matters related to foreign peoples and the "barbarians" of the four directions.) (Emperor Cheng added a Director for the Bureau of the Three Excellencies to supervise judicial matters and criminal trials.) (Supervisor (puye) was originally a Qin official title.) (The character pu means to supervise or be in charge.) (In ancient times, great importance was placed on military readiness; consequently, every office was required to have a "Master of Archery" to supervise and evaluate the training of the staff.) (Xie Gong served as the Supervisor of the Secretariat.) ) Emperor Guangwu then held a great feast for his soldiers, after which he moved east to lay siege to Julu. Wang Lang's defending general, Wang Rao, held the city firmly, and after more than a month, it had still not fallen. Wang Lang then dispatched his generals, Ni Hong and Liu Feng, (The character ni is pronounced ni.) ) leading several tens of thousands of men to relieve the siege of Julu. Emperor Guangwu moved to intercept them and engaged them in battle at Nanluan. (Nanluan was a county belonging to Julu Commandery; its former city is located northeast of present-day Bairen County in Xingzhou.) (The Zuo Zhuan records that Guo Xia of Qi attacked Jin and captured Luan; this was the same location.) (Since the settlement later moved further south, the word nan [south] was added to its name.) (Today it is commonly called Lun City, which is a phonetic corruption of the original name.) (The character luan is pronounced luan.) ) Several thousand heads were taken in the victory. In the fourth month, they advanced to besiege Handan and decisively defeated the enemy in a series of battles. On the jiachen day of the fifth month, they captured the city and executed Wang Lang. They collected various documents and discovered thousands of memorials from officials and commoners that had slandered and defamed the Han in their dealings with Wang Lang. Emperor Guangwu did not examine them; instead, he gathered his generals and had the documents burned, saying, "Let those who were wavering now find peace of mind." (The term fance means to be restless or uneasy.) (The Classic of Poetry, in the "Lessons from the States" section, states: "Tossing and turning, restless and uneasy.") )

æ›´å§‹é£ä¾å¾¡å²æŒç¯€ç«‹å…‰æ­¦ç‚ºè•­ç‹ï¼Œ ã€ˆè•­ï¼Œç¸£ï¼Œå±¬æ²›éƒ¡ï¼Œä»Šå¾å·ç¸£ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€ŠçºŒæ¼¢æ›¸ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ›´å§‹ä½¿ä¾å¾¡å²é»ƒé»¨å°ä¸Šç‚ºè•­ç‹ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ æ‚‰ä»¤ç½·å…µè©£è¡Œåœ¨æ‰€ã€‚ ã€ˆè”¡é‚•ç¨æ–·æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤©å­ä»¥å››æµ·ç‚ºå®¶ï¼Œæ•…è¬‚æ‰€å±…ç‚ºè¡Œåœ¨æ‰€ã€‚ ã€ã€‰ å…‰æ­¦è¾­ä»¥æ²³åŒ—æœªå¹³ï¼Œä¸å°±å¾µã€‚ è‡ªæ˜¯å§‹è²³æ–¼æ›´å§‹ã€‚ ã€ˆè²³ï¼Œé›¢ç•°ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰
Emperor Gengshi dispatched an Attendant Censor, bearing the imperial tally, to enfeoff Emperor Guangwu as the King of Xiao. (Xiao was a county belonging to Pei Commandery; it is present-day Xiao County in Xuzhou.) (The Continued Book of Han states: "Emperor Gengshi sent the Attendant Censor Huang Dang to enfeoff the Emperor as the King of Xiao.") ) He also ordered that all troops be demobilized and that Emperor Guangwu report to the imperial traveling residence. (Cai Yong states in his Du Duan: "Since the Son of Heaven treats the entire world as his home, wherever he happens to reside is called the 'traveling palace' (xingzaishuo).") ) Guangwu declined the summons, citing that Hebei remained unconquered. From this point onward, Guangwu began to show disloyalty toward Gengshi. (Er means separation or disloyalty.) )

æ˜¯æ™‚é•·å®‰æ”¿äº‚ï¼Œå››æ–¹èƒŒå›ã€‚ æ¢ç‹åŠ‰æ°¸æ“…å‘½ç¢é™½ï¼Œ ã€ˆç¸£åï¼Œå±¬æ¢éƒ¡ï¼Œä»Šå®‹å·ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ“…ï¼Œå°ˆä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ å…¬å­«è¿°ç¨±ç‹å·´èœ€ï¼Œ ã€ˆèœ€æœ‰å·´éƒ¡ï¼Œæ•…ç·«è¨€ä¹‹ã€‚ ã€‰ ææ†²è‡ªç«‹ç‚ºæ·®å—ç‹ï¼Œ ã€ˆæ·®å—ï¼Œéƒ¡ï¼Œä»Šå£½å·ä¹Ÿã€‚ ã€‰ ç§¦è±è‡ªè™Ÿæ¥šé»ç‹ï¼Œ ã€ˆç¿’é‘¿é½’è¥„é™½è¨˜æ›°ï¼šã€Œç§¦è±ï¼Œé»ä¸˜éƒ·äººã€‚ é»ä¸˜æ¥šåœ°ï¼Œæ•…ç¨±æ¥šé»ç‹ã€‚ ã€é»ä¸˜æ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šè¥„å·ç‡é“ç¸£åŒ—ã€‚ ã€‰ å¼µæ­¥èµ·ç…é‚ªï¼Œ ã€ˆéƒ¡æœ‰ç…é‚ªå±±ï¼Œæ•…åŸï¼Œä»Šæµ·å·æœå±±ç¸£æ±åŒ—ã€‚ ã€‰ è‘£æ†²èµ·æ±æµ·ï¼Œ ã€ˆéƒ¡åï¼Œä»Šæµ·å·ç¸£ã€‚ ã€‰ å»¶å²‘èµ·æ¼¢ä¸­ï¼Œ ã€ˆéƒ¡åï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šæ¢å·å—é„­ç¸£æ±åŒ—ã€‚ ã€‰ ç”°æˆèµ·å¤·é™µï¼Œ ã€ˆç¸£åï¼Œå±¬å—éƒ¡ã€‚ æœ‰å¤·å±±ï¼Œæ•…æ›°å¤·é™µï¼Œä»Šç¡¤å·ç¸£ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ•…åŸåœ¨ä»Šç¸£è¥¿åŒ—ã€‚ ã€‰ ä¸¦ç½®å°‡å¸¥ï¼Œä¾µç•¥éƒ¡ç¸£ã€‚ åˆåˆ¥è™Ÿè«¸è³ŠéŠ…é¦¬ã€å¤§è‚œã€é«˜æ¹–ã€é‡é€£ã€éµè„›ã€å¤§æ¶ã€å°¤ä¾†ã€ä¸Šæ±Ÿã€é’çŠ¢ã€äº”æ ¡ã€æª€éƒ·ã€äº”å¹¡ã€äº”æ¨“ã€å¯Œå¹³ã€ç²ç´¢ç­‰ï¼Œ ã€ˆè«¸è³Šæˆ–ä»¥å±±å·åœŸåœ°ç‚ºåï¼Œæˆ–ä»¥è»å®¹å½Šç››ç‚ºè™Ÿã€‚ éŠ…é¦¬è³Šå¸¥æ±å±±è’ç¦¿ã€ä¸Šæ·®æ³ç­‰ï¼Œå¤§è‚œæ¸ å¸¥æ¨Šé‡ï¼Œå°¤ä¾†æ¸ å¸¥æ¨Šå´‡ï¼Œäº”æ ¡è³Šå¸¥é«˜æ‰ˆï¼Œæª€éƒ·è³Šå¸¥è‘£æ¬¡ä»²ï¼Œäº”æ¨“è³Šå¸¥å¼µæ–‡ï¼Œå¯Œå¹³è³Šå¸¥å¾å°‘ï¼Œç²ç´¢è³Šå¸¥å¤å¸«éƒç­‰ï¼Œä¸¦è¦‹æ±è§€è¨˜ã€‚ ã€‰ å„é ˜éƒ¨æ›²ï¼Œ ã€ˆã€ŠçºŒæ¼¢å¿—ã€‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤§å°‡è»ç‡Ÿæœ‰äº”éƒ¨ï¼Œéƒ¨ä¸‰æ ¡å°‰ã€‚ éƒ¨ä¸‹æœ‰æ›²ï¼Œæ›²æœ‰è»å€™ä¸€äººã€‚ ã€ã€‰ è¡†åˆæ•¸ç™¾è¬äººï¼Œæ‰€åœ¨å¯‡æ ã€‚
At this time, political chaos reigned in Chang'an and rebellions broke out in all four directions. King Liu Yong of Liang ruled independently in Suiyang, (Suiyang was a county in Liang commandery, now Songzhou.) (Shan means to monopolize or act independently.) ) Gongsun Shu declared himself king of Bashu, (Shu contains Ba commandery, hence the collective name Bashu.) ) Li Xian proclaimed himself King of Huainan, (Huainan was a commandery, now Shouzhou.) ) Qin Feng proclaimed himself King of Chu and Li, (Xi Zaochi's Records of Xiangyang states: 'Qin Feng was from Liqiu Township.') Liqiu was located in Chu territory, hence the title King of Chu and Li. The ruins of ancient Liqiu are located north of modern Shuidao County in Xiangzhou. ) Zhang Bu rose in rebellion in Langye, (The commandery contains Mount Langye; its ancient city lies northeast of modern Qushan County in Haizhou.) ) Dong Xian rose in rebellion in Donghai, (Commandery name, now Haizhou County.) ) Yan Cen rose in rebellion in Hanzhong, (Commandery name; its ancient city lies northeast of modern Nanzheng County in Liangzhou.) ) Tian Rong rose in rebellion in Yiling, (County name, belonging to Nangun.) It contains Mount Yi, hence the name Yiling; now Qiaozhou County, with the ancient city northwest of the modern county. ) They all established generals and commanders, raiding and pillaging the commanderies and counties. They also separately named various bandit groups: Copper Horse, Great Shape, High Lake, Heavy Link, Iron Shin, Great Plunder, Especially Come, Upper River, Blue Calf, Five Schools, Tan Township, Five Banners, Five Towers, Rich Plain, Obtain Rope, and others, (The various bandits either took names from mountains, rivers, and territories, or were named for their formidable military bearing.) Copper Horse bandit leader Dongshan Huangtu, Shang Huaikuang and others; Great Shape leader Fan Chong; Especially Come leader Fan Chong; Five Schools bandit leader Gao Hu; Tan Township bandit leader Dong Cizhong; Five Towers bandit leader Zhang Wen; Rich Plain bandit leader Xu Shao; Obtain Rope bandit leader Gu Shilang and othersâ€”all appear in the Records of the Eastern Tower. ) Each commanding their own divisions and troops, (The Continued Han Records states: 'The Grand General's camp has five divisions, each with three colonels.') Under each division are companies, and each company has one army captain. ") Their combined forces numbered several hundred thousand, pillaging wherever they appeared.

Guangwu prepared to attack them, first dispatching Wu Han north to raise troops from ten commanderies. Governor Miao Zeng of Youzhou refused to comply, so Han executed Zeng and mobilized his forces. In autumn, Guangwu attacked the Copper Horse bandits at Qiang, (County name, belonging to Julu commandery; ancient city east of modern Lucheng County in Jizhou.) (Qiang is pronounced ku yao fan.) (The Bamboo Annals states: 'Wei Yang was enfeoffed at Qiang.') (Minister Xian notes: The text below mentions 'Wu Han led the assault cavalry to meet at Qingyang' and 'pursued to Guantao', both near Qiang.) (Popular editions often mistakenly write it as 'Wu'; Xiao Gai pronounces it yi gu fan, claiming it belongs to Taiyuan commandery; Zang Jin pronounces it as Yan, yi jian fan, claiming it belongs to Xiangyang commanderyâ€”all are incorrect.) ) Wu Han led the assault cavalry to rendezvous at Qingyang. (County name, belonging to Qinghe commandery; now Beizhou County, with ancient city northwest of the prefecture.) ) The bandits repeatedly challenged them to combat, (To step forward and fight alone; anciently called 'issuing a challenge to battle'; see the Zuo Commentary.) (Tiao is pronounced tu liao fan.) ) Guangwu fortified his camp and held his position; Whenever bandits sallied forth to plunder, he would promptly attack and seize them, (Lu means the same as lu [to plunder].) (Guo Pu's commentary on the Erya states: 'Lue means to seize and take.') ") cutting off their supply lines. After more than a month, the bandits ran out of food and fled under cover of night; he pursued them to Guantao and inflicted a major defeat. (Guantao was a county in Wei commandery, now Weizhou county.) ) The surrender was still incomplete when Gao Hu and Chong Lian arrived from the southeast, joining forces with the remaining Copper Horse bandits. Guangwu fought another major battle against them at Puyang, decisively defeating them all and enfeoffing their leaders as marquises. (The Former Book's glossary states: 'Puyang Mountain is the source of the Pu River,' located northwest of modern Beiping County in Dingzhou.) (Some editions write it as 'Manyang'.) (Qu means great or chief.) (The Book of Documents states: 'Slaughter their chief leaders.') (Marquises are also known as chehou [full marquises].) The term 'lie' means they are listed in the sequence of nobility.) ) The surrendered troops still felt unsettled. Guangwu understood their concerns and ordered each group to return to their camps to organize their forces, while he personally rode a light horse to inspect their battle formations. The surrendered soldiers said among themselves: 'King Xiao lays his true heart bare in our belliesâ€”how can we not die for him!' (Tou si means to devote oneself completely to death.) ) From this point onward, all were convinced and submitted. He distributed all the surrendered troops among his various generals, swelling his army to several hundred thousand. This is why west of the pass they called Guangwu the 'Copper Horse Emperor.' A separate Red Eyebrow commander, along with the leaders of Great Shape and Blue Calf bands with over a hundred thousand troops, was stationed at Shegou, (The Continued Han Records states that Yewang County contains the Shegou settlement; its ancient site lies north of modern Wude County in Huai Prefecture.) ) Guangwu advanced and attacked, decisively defeating them. Their troops scattered and fled in all directions. He dispatched Wu Han and Cen Peng to attack and assassinate Xie Gong at Ye.

The Blue Calf and Red Eyebrow bandits entered Hangu Pass and attacked Gengshi. (Hangu is the name of a valley; the pass takes its name from the valley.) It was formerly located west of Hucheng County in Hongnong. The Former Book states that Yang Pu served as Tower Ship General and, having achieved merit, was ashamed to live outside the pass. Emperor Wu then relocated it to Xin'an. Hence the pass is located east of modern Xin'an County in Luo Prefecture. ) Guangwu then dispatched Deng Yu, commanding six deputy generals, to lead troops west and exploit the turmoil between Gengshi and the Red Eyebrows. At this time, Gengshi dispatched Grand Marshal Zhu Wei, King Li Yi of Wuyin, and others to garrison Luoyang, (Wuyin was a county in Nanyang commandery; its ancient site lies northwest of modern Biyang County in Tang Prefecture.) ) Guangwu also commanded Feng Yi to defend Mengjin and hold them back. (Kong Anguo's commentary on the Book of Documents states: 'Meng is a place name north of Luo where all roads converge; both ancient and modern times consider it a river crossing.) (The Lunheng states: 'When King Wu attacked Zhou, eight hundred feudal lords formed their alliance here, hence it is called Mengjin.) (It is popularly called Zhishu Ford, and is now the river crossing at Heyang County.) )

Guangwu attacked north against the Especially Come, Great Plunder, and Five Banners forces at Yuanshi, pursuing them to Right Beiping where he successively defeated them. (Beiping was a county in the Principality of Zhongshan, now Yongle County in Yizhou.) (Minister Xian notes: Neither the Records of the Eastern Tower nor the Continued Book of Han include the character 'right'; this addition is erroneous.) There is separately a Right Beiping commandery ancient city southwest of Ying Prefecture, which is not this location. ) He fought another battle north of the Shun River, (Li Yuan's Commentary on the Water Classic states: 'The Xu River flows north of the ancient city of Beiping County. Guangwu pursued the Copper Horse and Five Banners forces, defeating them at Shun Riverâ€”which is another name for the Xu River.') It is located in modern Yizhou.) Some editions write it as 'Shen,' which is incorrect.) ) Pressing his advantage with a rash advance, he was instead defeated by them. The bandits pressed their pursuit fiercely, engaging in close-quarters combat, (Short weapons mean knives and swords.) (The Songs of Chu states: 'Chariots tangled their axles, short weapons engaged.') ") Guangwu leaped onto the high bank and encountered assault cavalryman Wang Feng, who dismounted to help him up. Guangwu patted his shoulder and mounted the horse, then turned and laughed to Geng Yan: 'I almost became a laughingstock for the captives.' Yan repeatedly shot arrows to drive back the bandits, allowing them to escape. Several thousand soldiers died, and the scattered troops retreated to defend Fanyang. (County name, located on the north bank of the Fan River in Zhuojun commandery; ancient city southeast of modern Yi County in Yizhou.) ) Guangwu was nowhere to be seen in the army, and some claimed he had already perished, (The Records of the Eastern Tower states: 'The Emperor had already arrived first, riding Wang Feng's small horse; the camp gate guards were unaware.') ") The generals were at a loss for what to do. Wu Han said: 'Gentlemen, give it your all!' (Cao means 'group' or 'company of people.') ) The king's elder brother's sons are in Nanyangâ€”why worry about having no leader?" (By 'brother's sons' he means Bosheng's sons, Zhang and Xing.) ) The troops were gripped by fear, but after several days they settled down. Although the bandits had won the battle, they were long intimidated by the emperor's overwhelming might, (Zhe means to fear or be intimidated, pronounced zhi she fan.) ) Since the two sides did not recognize each other, they withdrew under cover of night. The main army advanced once more to Anci, (Anci was a county in Bohai commandery; now Youzhou county, with its ancient site east of the modern county.) ) They engaged them in battle, defeated them, and took over three thousand heads. The bandits entered Yuyang, so Guangwu dispatched Wu Han, commanding Geng Yan, Chen Jun, Ma Wu, and eleven other generals to pursue and engage them east of Lu, (Lu was a county in Yuyang commandery, now Youzhou county.) It took its name from the Lu River that flows through the area. (Xiao Gai's glossary states: 'Lu belongs to Shangdang.') (Minister Xian notes: Lu borders Yuyang; the claim that it belongs to Shangdang is incorrect.) ) They reached Pinggu and decisively defeated and annihilated the enemy forces. (Pinggu was a county in Yuyang commandery; its ancient site lies north of modern Lu county.) )

Zhu Wei dispatched General Su Mao, who was tasked with suppressing rebellions, to attack Wen, (Now Luozhou county.) ) Feng Yi and Kou Xun engaged them in battle, decisively defeated them, and executed their general Jia Qiang.

Thereupon the generals discussed conferring an honorific title upon him. Ma Wu stepped forward first and said: 'The realm has no ruler.' Even if a sage were to arise and take charge in these troubled timesâ€”even with Confucius as chancellor and Sun Tzu as generalâ€”I fear they could accomplish nothing worthwhile. What's done cannot be undoneâ€”like spilt water that cannot be gathered backâ€”regret will come too late. (He means that Guangwu should have assumed the imperial position early to stabilize people's loyalties; now his modesty and reluctance miss the critical moment.) Sun Tzu, whose name was Wu, served as general to King HelÃ¼ of Wu. He was skilled in military strategy and authored thirteen chapters on the art of war. (Fan is pronounced fan.) ) Though you, Great King, practice modesty and decline the throneâ€”what of the ancestral temples and the altars of the state! For now, you should return to Ji, assume the imperial position, and only then discuss military campaigns. Who are these bandits that you gallop about fighting against?" (Shui means there is no ruler as yet.) (The Former Book's glossary states: 'Straight galloping is called chi; disordered galloping is called wu.') ") Guangwu was shocked and said: 'Why does the general utter such words?' He deserves execution! Wu said: 'All the generals feel the same way.' Guangwu sent him out to make them understand, (Sent to enlighten the generals.) ) Then he led the army back to Ji.
